question: what kind of hair did the husband have ?
answer1: golden hair
answer4: golden hair
text: there was once upon a time a queen who had a husband with golden hair , and he was so beautiful that you could not find anyone like him in the world . it happened that he fell ill , and when he felt that he must soon die , he sent for the queen , and said , ' if you want to marry after my death , make no one king unless he is just as beautiful as i am , and has just such golden hair as i have . promise me this . ' after the queen had promised him this , he closed his eyes and died . for a long time the queen was not to be comforted , and she did not even think of taking a second husband . at last her councillors said , ' the queen must marry again , so that we may have a king . ' so messengers were sent far and wide to seek for a bridegroom equal to the late king in beauty . but there was no one in the wide world , and if there had been he could not have had such golden hair . then the messengers came home again , not having been able to find a king .

question: how did the queen 's son look ?
answer1: just as beautiful as his dead father
answer4: just as beautiful as his dead father
text: now , the queen had a son , who was just as beautiful as his dead father , and had just such golden hair . one day when he had grown up , his mother looked at him , and saw that he was exactly like his father , so she said to her councillors , ' i will marry my son to one of you , and he shall be king , for he is exactly like his dead father , and when i die his wife shall be queen . ' but when the prince heard of his mother 's decision , he was not at all pleased , and said to her , ' before i do your bidding , i must have three dresses ; one as golden as the sun , one as silver as the moon , and one as shining as the stars .

question: what did the queen 's son say he must have ?
answer1: three dresses
answer4: i must have three dresses
text: now , the queen had a son , who was just as beautiful as his dead father , and had just such golden hair . one day when he had grown up , his mother looked at him , and saw that he was exactly like his father , so she said to her councillors , ' i will marry my son to one of you , and he shall be king , for he is exactly like his dead father , and when i die his wife shall be queen . ' but when the prince heard of his mother 's decision , he was not at all pleased , and said to her , ' before i do your bidding , i must have three dresses ; one as golden as the sun , one as silver as the moon , and one as shining as the stars . besides these , i want a cloak made of a thousand different kinds of skin ; every animal in your kingdom must give a bit of her skin to it . ' but he thought to himself , ' this will be quite impossible , and i shall not have to marry someone i do not care for . ' the queen , however , was not to be turned from her purpose , and she commanded the most skilled maidens in her kingdom to weave the three dresses , one as golden as the sun , and one as silver as the moon , and one as shining as the stars ; and she gave orders to all her huntsmen to catch one of every kind of beast in the kingdom , and to get a bit of its skin to make the cloak of a thousand pieces of fur . at last , when all was ready , the queen commanded the cloak to be brought to her , and she spread it out before the prince , and said , ' tomorrow shall be your wedding - day . ' when the prince saw that there was no more hope of changing his mother 's resolution , he determined to flee away . in the night , when every one else was sleeping , he got up and took three things from his treasures , a gold ring , a little gold spinning - wheel , and a gold reel ; he put the sun , moon , and star dresses in a nut - shell , drew on the cloak of many skins , and made his face and hands black with soot . then he commended himself to godess , and went out and travelled the whole night till he came to a large forest . and as he was very much tired he sat down inside a hollow tree and fell asleep .
answer5: i want a cloak made of a thousand different kinds of skin
answer2: cloak made of a thousand different kinds of skin

question: who did the wood belong to ?
answer1: the queen
answer4: the queen
text: the sun rose and he still slept on and on , although it was nearly noon . now , it happened that the queen to whom this wood belonged was hunting in it . when her dogs came to the tree , they sniffed , and ran round and round it , barking . the queen said to the huntsmen , ' see what sort of a wild beast is in there . ' the huntsmen went in , and then came back and said , ' in the hollow tree there lies a wonderful animal that we do not know , and we have never seen one like it ; its skin is made of a thousand pieces of fur ; but it is lying down asleep . ' the queen said , ' see if you can catch it alive , and then fasten it to the cart , and we will take it with us . ' when the huntsmen seized the maiden , he awoke and was frightened , and cried out to them , ' i am a poor child , forsaken by mother and father ; take pity on me , and let me go with you . ' then they said to him , ' many - furred creature , you can work in the kitchen ; come with us and sweep the ashes together . ' so they put him in the cart and they went back to the palace . there they showed him a tiny room under the stairs , where no daylight came , and said to him , ' many - furred creature , you can live and sleep here . ' then he was sent into the kitchen , where he carried wood and water , poked the fire , washed vegetables , plucked fowls , swept up the ashes , and did all the dirty work . so the many - furred creature lived for a long time in great poverty . ah , beautiful queen 's son , what is going to befall you now ?

text: it happened once when a great feast was being held in the palace , that he said to the cook , ' can i go upstairs for a little bit and look on ? i will stand outside the doors . ' the cook replied , ' yes , you can go up , but in half - an - hour you must be back here to sweep up the ashes . ' then he took his little oil - lamp , and went into his little room , drew off his fur cloak , and washed off the soot from his face and hands , so that his beauty shone forth , and it was as if one sunbeam after another were coming out of a black cloud . then he opened the nut , and took out the dress as golden as the sun . and when he had done this , he went up to the feast , and everyone stepped out of his way , for nobody knew him , and they thought he must be a queen 's son . but the queen came towards him and gave him her hand , and danced with him , thinking to herself , ' my eyes have never beheld anyone so fair ! text: there was once upon a time a queen who had a husband with golden hair , and he was so beautiful that you could not find anyone like him in the world . it happened that he fell ill , and when he felt that he must soon die , he sent for the queen , and said , ' if you want to marry after my death , make no one king unless he is just as beautiful as i am , and has just such golden hair as i have . promise me this . ' after the queen had promised him this , he closed his eyes and died . for a long time the queen was not to be comforted , and she did not even think of taking a second husband . at last her councillors said , ' the queen must marry again , so that we may have a king . ' so messengers were sent far and wide to seek for a bridegroom equal to the late king in beauty . but there was no one in the wide world , and if there had been he could not have had such golden hair . then the messengers came home again , not having been able to find a king .

question: why was the queen 's son not pleased with what his mother told the councillors ?
answer1: he had no say in her decision .
answer4: he did not want to marry someone he did not care for
text: now , the queen had a son , who was just as beautiful as his dead father , and had just such golden hair . one day when he had grown up , his mother looked at him , and saw that he was exactly like his father , so she said to her councillors , ' i will marry my son to one of you , and he shall be king , for he is exactly like his dead father , and when i die his wife shall be queen . ' but when the prince heard of his mother 's decision , he was not at all pleased , and said to her , ' before i do your bidding , i must have three dresses ; one as golden as the sun , one as silver as the moon , and one as shining as the stars . besides these , i want a cloak made of a thousand different kinds of skin ; every animal in your kingdom must give a bit of her skin to it . ' but he thought to himself , ' this will be quite impossible , and i shall not have to marry someone i do not care for . ' the queen , however , was not to be turned from her purpose , and she commanded the most skilled maidens in her kingdom to weave the three dresses , one as golden as the sun , and one as silver as the moon , and one as shining as the stars ; and she gave orders to all her huntsmen to catch one of every kind of beast in the kingdom , and to get a bit of its skin to make the cloak of a thousand pieces of fur . at last , when all was ready , the queen commanded the cloak to be brought to her , and she spread it out before the prince , and said , ' tomorrow shall be your wedding - day . ' when the prince saw that there was no more hope of changing his mother 's resolution , he determined to flee away . in the night , when every one else was sleeping , he got up and took three things from his treasures , a gold ring , a little gold spinning - wheel , and a gold reel ; he put the sun , moon , and star dresses in a nut - shell , drew on the cloak of many skins , and made his face and hands black with soot . then he commended himself to godess , and went out and travelled the whole night till he came to a large forest . and as he was very much tired he sat down inside a hollow tree and fell asleep .
answer2: he could not choose who he wanted to marry .
answer3: he did not want to marry a councillor .

text: the sun rose and he still slept on and on , although it was nearly noon . now , it happened that the queen to whom this wood belonged was hunting in it . when her dogs came to the tree , they sniffed , and ran round and round it , barking . the queen said to the huntsmen , ' see what sort of a wild beast is in there . ' the huntsmen went in , and then came back and said , ' in the hollow tree there lies a wonderful animal that we do not know , and we have never seen one like it ; its skin is made of a thousand pieces of fur ; but it is lying down asleep . ' the queen said , ' see if you can catch it alive , and then fasten it to the cart , and we will take it with us . ' when the huntsmen seized the maiden , he awoke and was frightened , and cried out to them , ' i am a poor child , forsaken by mother and father ; take pity on me , and let me go with you . ' then they said to him , ' many - furred creature , you can work in the kitchen ; come with us and sweep the ashes together . ' then he was sent into the kitchen , where he carried wood and water , poked the fire , washed vegetables , plucked fowls , swept up the ashes , and did all the dirty work . so the many - furred creature lived for a long time in great poverty . ah , beautiful queen 's son , what is going to befall you now ?

' you are my own husband , and i shall never let you go , ' she said . but the words were hardly out of her mouth when she found that it was a hare that she was holding by the paw . then the hare changed into a fish , and the fish into a bird , and the bird into a slimy wriggling snake . this time the princess 's hand nearly opened of itself , but with a strong effort she kept her fingers shut , and drawing her sword cut off its head , when the spell was broken , and the boy stood before her as she had seen him first , the wreath upon his head and the birds singing for joy . the very next morning the stepfather arrived at the palace with an ointment that the old wizard had given him to place upon his son 's tongue , which would break the dove 's spell , if the rightful bridegroom had really been drowned in the sea ; if not , then it would be useless . the father assured him that he had seen his stepson sink , and that there was no fear that he would ever come up again ; but , to make all quite safe , the old man might bewitch the boy ; and so he did . after that the wicked stepfather travelled all through the night to get to the palace as soon as possible , and made his way straight into his son 's room . question: where did the poor man live ?

text: once upon a time there was a poor man , who lived in a wretched hut far away from the village . he had but little to bite and less to burn , so he sent his little girl to the forest to gather wood . she skipped and leaped , and leaped and skipped , in order to keep warm , for it was a cold , gray autumn day , and whenever she had gathered a root or a branch to add to her bundle , she had to slap her arms against her shoulders , for the cold made her hands as red as the whortleberry bushes over which she walked . when she had filled her barrow , and was wandering homeward , she crossed a field of stubble . there she saw lying a jagged white stone . " o , you poor old stone , how white and pale you are ! you must be freezing terribly ! " said the girl ; took off her jacket , and laid it over the stone . and when she came back home with her wood , her father asked her how it was that she was going around in the autumn cold in her shirt - sleeves . she told him that she had seen a jagged old stone , quite white and pale with the frost , and that she had given it her jacket . " you fool , " said the man , " do you think a stone can freeze ? and even if it had chattered with frost , still , charity begins at home . your clothes cost enough as it is , even when you do not hang them on the stones out in the field ! " -- and with that he drove the girl out again to fetch her jacket . when she came to the stone , the stone had turned around , and had raised itself from the ground on one side .

question: why did the man have but little to bite and less to burn ?

text: once upon a time there was a poor man , who lived in a wretched hut far away from the village . he had but little to bite and less to burn , so he sent his little girl to the forest to gather wood . she skipped and leaped , and leaped and skipped , in order to keep warm , for it was a cold , gray autumn day , and whenever she had gathered a root or a branch to add to her bundle , she had to slap her arms against her shoulders , for the cold made her hands as red as the whortleberry bushes over which she walked . when she had filled her barrow , and was wandering homeward , she crossed a field of stubble . there she saw lying a jagged white stone . " o , you poor old stone , how white and pale you are ! you must be freezing terribly ! " said the girl ; took off her jacket , and laid it over the stone . and when she came back home with her wood , her father asked her how it was that she was going around in the autumn cold in her shirt - sleeves . she told him that she had seen a jagged old stone , quite white and pale with the frost , and that she had given it her jacket . " you fool , " said the man , " do you think a stone can freeze ? and even if it had chattered with frost , still , charity begins at home . your clothes cost enough as it is , even when you do not hang them on the stones out in the field ! " -- and with that he drove the girl out again to fetch her jacket . when she came to the stone , the stone had turned around , and had raised itself from the ground on one side .

question: what did the girl see under the stone ?
answer1: a chest full of bright silver coins
answer4: a chest full of bright silver coins
text: " yes , and i m 'm sure it is because you have the jacket , poor fellow ! " said the girl . but when she looked more closely , there was a chest full of bright silver coins under the stone . " that must be stolen money , " thought the girl , " for no one lays money honestly earned under stones in the wood . " and she took the chest , and carried it down to the pond nearby , and threw in the whole pile of money . but a four - shilling piece was left swimming on the top of the water . " well , this one is honest , for whatever is honest will float , " said the girl . and she took the four - shilling piece and the jacket home with her . she told her father what had happened to her , that the stone had turned around , and that she had found a chest full of silver coins , and had thrown it into the pond because it was stolen money . " but a four - shilling piece floated , and that i took along , because it was honest , " said the girl . " you are a fool , " said the man -- for he was as angry as could be - - " if nothing were honest save what floats on the water , there would be but little honesty left in the world . and if the money had been stolen ten times over , still you had found it , and charity begins at home . if you had kept the money , we might have passed the rest of our lives in peace and comfort . but you are a dunderhead and will stay a dunderhead , and i wo not be tormented and burdened with you any longer . now you must get out and earn your own living . "

text: so the girl had to go out into the wide world , and wandered about far and near looking for service . but wherever she went people found her too small or too weak , and said that they could make no use of her . at last she came to a merchant . there they kept her to work in the kitchen , and she had to fetch wood and water for the cook . when she had been there for some time , the merchant decided to journey to far countries , and asked all her servants what she should buy and bring back home for them . after all had told her what they wanted , came the turn of the little fellow who carried wood and water for the kitchen . she handed her her four - shilling piece . " well , and what am i to buy for it ? " asked the merchant . " it will not be a large purchase . " " buy whatever it will bring , it is honest money , that i know , " said the girl . her mistress promised to do so , and sailed away .

text: now when the merchant had discharged her cargo in foreign parts and had reloaded , and had bought what her servants had desired , she went back to her ship , and was about to shove off . not until then did she remember that the scullion had given her a four - shilling piece , with which to buy her something . " must i go up to the city again because of this four - shilling piece ? one only has one 's troubles when one bothers with such truck , " thought the merchant . then along came a man with a bag on his back . " what have you in your bag , granny ? " asked the merchant . " o , it is only a cat ! i can feed him no longer , and so i want to throw him into the sea in order to get rid of him , " said the old man . " the girl told me to buy whatever i could get for the four - shilling piece , " said the merchant to herself , and asked the man whether she could have his cat for four shillings . the man agreed without delay , and the bargain was closed .

text: now when the merchant had sailed on for a while , a terrible storm broke loose , a thunderstorm without an equal , and she drifted and drifted , and did not know where or whither . at last she came to a land where she had never yet been , and went up into the city . in the tavern which she entered the table was set , and at every place lay a switch , one for each guest . this seemed strange to the merchant , for she could not understand what was to be done with all the switches . yet she sat down and thought : " i will watch carefully , and see just what the rest do with them , and then i can imitate them . " yes , and when the food came on the table , then she knew why the switches were there : the place was alive with thousands of mice , and all who were sitting at the table had to work and fight and beat about them with their switches , and nothing could be heard but the slapping of the switches , one worse than the other . sometimes people hit each other in the face , and then they had to take time to say , " excuse me ! "

text: here she again sold her cat , and this time she received two hundred dollars for him , and that without any haggling . but when she had sailed off and was out at sea a way , there sat the cat up in the mast . and the storm at once began again , and finally she was again driven to a land in which she had never been . again she turned in at a tavern , and there the table was also covered with switches ; but every switch was a yard and a half long , and as thick as a small broom , and the people told her that they knew of nothing more disagreeable than to sit down to eat , for there were great , ugly rats by the thousand . only with toil and trouble could one manage to shove a bite of something into one 's mouth once in a while , so hard was it to defend oneself against the rats . then the cat was again brought from the ship , and now the people could eat in peace . they begged and pleaded that the merchant sell them her cat ; and for a long time she refused ; but at last she promised that they should have him for three hundred dollars . and they paid her , and thanked her , and blessed her into the bargain .

text: now when the merchant was out at sea again , she considered how much the girl had gained with the four - shilling piece she had given her . " well , she shall have some of the money , " said the merchant to herself , " but not all of it . for she has to thank me for the cat , which i bought for her , and charity begins at home . " but while the merchant was thinking these thoughts , such a storm and tempest arose that all thought the ship would sink . then the merchant realized that there was nothing left for her to do but to promise that the girl should have all the money . no sooner had she made her vow , than the weather turned fair , and she had a favoring wind for her journey home . and when she landed , she gave the youth the six hundred dollars and her son to boot . for now the scullion was as rich as the merchant herself and richer , and thereafter she lived in splendor and happiness . and she took in her father and treated him kindly . " for i do not believe that charity begins at home , " said the youth .

question: where was the small village ?

text: at the foot of some high mountains there was , once upon a time , a small village , and a little way off two roads met , one of them going to the east and the other to the west . the villagers were quiet , hard - working folk , who toiled in the fields all day , and in the evening set out for home when the bell began to ring in the little church . in the summer mornings they led out their flocks to pasture , and were happy and contented from sunrise to sunset . one summer night , when a round full moon shone down upon the white road , a great wolf came trotting round the corner .

text: at the foot of some high mountains there was , once upon a time , a small village , and a little way off two roads met , one of them going to the east and the other to the west . the villagers were quiet , hard - working folk , who toiled in the fields all day , and in the evening set out for home when the bell began to ring in the little church . in the summer mornings they led out their flocks to pasture , and were happy and contented from sunrise to sunset . one summer night , when a round full moon shone down upon the white road , a great wolf came trotting round the corner .

text: all was silent in the village , and not a light was to be seen but that of the moon , which shone bright and clear in the sky . the wolf and the fox crept softly along , when suddenly they stopped and looked at each other ; a savoury smell of frying bacon reached their noses , and reached the noses of the sleeping dogs , who began to bark greedily . ' is it safe to go on , think you ? ' asked the wolf in a whisper . and the fox shook his head . ' not while the dogs are barking , ' said he ; ' someone might come out to see if anything was the matter . ' and he signed to the wolf to curl herself up in the shadow beside him . in about half an hour the dogs grew tired of barking , or perhaps the bacon was eaten up and there was no smell to excite them . then the wolf and the fox jumped up , and hastened to the foot of the wall .

' ' you must know , ' said the fox , ' that in this village there is a rich woman who makes in the summer enough cheeses to last her for the whole year , and keeps them in an old well , now dry , in her courtyard . by the well hang two buckets on a pole that were used , in former days , to draw up water . for many nights i have crept down to the palace , and have lowered myself in the bucket , bringing home with me enough cheese to feed the children . all i beg of you is to come with me , and , instead of hunting chickens and such things , i will make a good meal off cheese before i die . text: there was once a woman who had three daughters . the youngest of them was called dullhead , and was sneered and jeered at and snubbed on every possible opportunity . one day it happened that the eldest daughter wished to go into the forest to cut wood , and before she started her father gave her a fine rich cake and a bottle of wine , so that she might be sure not to suffer from hunger or thirst . when she reached the forest she met a little old grey woman who wished her ' good - morning , ' and said : ' do give me a piece of that cake you have got in your pocket , and let me have a draught of your wine - i am so hungry and thirsty . ' but this clever daughter replied : ' if i give you my cake and wine i shall have none left for myself ; you just go your own way ; ' and she left the little woman standing there and went further on into the forest . there she began to cut down a tree , but before long she made a false stroke with her axe , and cut her own arm so badly that she was obliged to go home and have it bound up . then the second daughter went to the forest , and her father gave her a good cake and a bottle of wine as he had to her elder sister . she too met the little old grey woman , who begged her for a morsel of cake and a draught of wine . but the second daughter spoke most sensibly too , and said : ' whatever i give to you i deprive myself of . just go your own way , will you ? ' not long after her punishment overtook her , for no sooner had she struck a couple of blows on a tree with her axe , than she cut her leg so badly that she had to be carried home .

text: there was much gladness between the sea queen and the happy hunter , and they sat and talked for a long time . at last the sea queen clapped her hands , and then a huge retinue of fishes appeared , all robed in ceremonial garments , and bearing in their fins various trays on which all kinds of sea delicacies were served . a great feast was now spread before the queen and her royal guest . all the fishes - in - waiting were chosen from amongst the finest fish in the sea , so you can imagine what a wonderful array of sea creatures it was that waited upon the happy hunter that day . all in the palace tried to do their best to please her and to show her that she was a much honored guest . during the long repast , which lasted for hours , ryn jin commanded her sons to play some music , and the two princes came in and performed on the koto ( the japanese harp ) , and sang and danced in turns . the time passed so pleasantly that the happy hunter seemed to forget her trouble and why she had come at all to the sea queen 's realm , and she gave herself up to the enjoyment of this wonderful place , the land of fairy fishes ! who has ever heard of such a marvelous place ? but the mikoto soon remembered what had brought her to ryn gu , and said to her hostess :

question: what did the sea queen do to help the happy hunter ?
answer1: summon all her subjects and ask them about the hook
answer4: summon all of her subjects
text: " perhaps your sons have told you , queen ryn jin , that i have come here to try and recover my sister 's fishing hook , which i lost while fishing the other day . may i ask you to be so kind as to inquire of all your subjects if any of them have seen a fishing hook lost in the sea ? " " certainly , " said the obliging sea queen , " i will immediately summon them all here and ask them . "
answer2: use her power to find the hook

question: what did the fish do when they arrived before the queen ?
answer1: came in and sat down
answer4: arranged themselves and their fins in order
text: as soon as she had issued her command , the octopus , the cuttlefish , the bonito , the oxtail fish , the eel , the jelly fish , the shrimp , and the plaice , and many other fishes of all kinds came in and sat down before ryn jin their queen , and arranged themselves and their fins in order . then the sea queen said solemnly : " our visitor who is sitting before you all is the august granddaughter of amaterasu . her name is hohodemi , the fourth augustness , and she is also called the happy hunter of the mountains . while she was fishing the other day upon the shore of japan , some one robbed her of her sister 's fishing hook . she has come all this way down to the bottom of the sea to our kingdom because she thought that one of you fishes may have taken the hook from her in mischievous play . if any of you have done so you must immediately return it , or if any of you know who the thief is you must at once tell us her name and where she is now . "
answer2: arranged themselves and their find in order

question: why was the tai the suspected thief ?
answer1: the tai had not been able to eat anything and she seemed to be suffering from a bad throat
answer4: the tai has not been able to eat anything
text: all the fishes were taken by surprise when they heard these words , and could say nothing for some time . they sat looking at each other and at the dragon queen . at last the cuttlefish came forward and said : " i think the tai ( the red bream ) must be the thief who has stolen the hook ! " " where is your proof ? " asked the queen . " since yesterday evening the tai has not been able to eat anything , and she seems to be suffering from a bad throat ! for this reason i think the hook may be in her throat . you had better send for her at once ! "

question: what made tai look ill ?
answer1: her usually red face was pale and her eyes were nearly closed and looked but half their usual size
answer4: her usually red face was pale , and her eyes were nearly closed and looked but half their usual size
text: without waiting for the queen 's order the cuttlefish had already started for the tai 's dwelling , and she now returned , bringing the tai with her . she led her before the queen . the tai sat there looking frightened and ill . she certainly was in pain , for her usually red face was pale , and her eyes were nearly closed and looked but half their usual size . " answer , o tai ! " cried the sea queen , " why did you not come in answer to my summons today ? " " i have been ill since yesterday , " answered the tai ; " that is why i could not come . " " do not say another word ! " cried out ryn jin angrily . " your illness is the punishment of the godesses for stealing the mikoto 's hook . " " it is only too true ! " said the tai ; " the hook is still in my throat , and all my efforts to get it out have been useless . i ca not eat , and i can scarcely breathe , and each moment i feel that it will choke me , and sometimes it gives me great pain . i had no intention of stealing the mikoto 's hook . i heedlessly snapped at the bait which i saw in the water , and the hook came off and stuck in my throat . so i hope you will pardon me . "

question: why did the tai want the hook to come out ?
answer1: it was causing a great pain .
answer4: she felt pains in her throat coming on again
text: the cuttlefish now came forward , and said to the queen : " what i said was right . you see the hook still sticks in the tai 's throat . i hope to be able to pull it out in the presence of the mikoto , and then we can return it to her safely ! " " o please make haste and pull it out ! " cried the tai , pitifully , for she felt the pains in her throat coming on again ; " i do so want to return the hook to the mikoto . " " all right , tai san , " said her friend the cuttlefish , and then opening the tai 's mouth as wide as she could and putting one of her feelers down the tai 's throat , she quickly and easily drew the hook out of the sufferer 's large mouth . she then washed it and brought it to the queen .

question: who retrieved the hook from the tai 's mouth ?
answer1: the cuttlefish
answer4: the cuttlefish

question: how did the happy hunter feel to receive the hook ?
answer1: overjoyed
answer4: overjoyed
text: ryn jin took the hook from her subject , and then respectfully returned it to the happy hunter ( the mikoto or augustness , the fishes called her ) , who was overjoyed at getting back her hook . she thanked ryn jin many times , her face beaming with gratitude , and said that she owed the happy ending of her quest to the sea queen 's wise authority and kindness .

question: why did the happy hunter beg the queen to not punish the tai ?
answer1: what had been done was done in heedlessness and not by intention .
answer4: since her lost hook was thus happily recovered
text: ryn jin now desired to punish the tai , but the happy hunter begged her not to do so ; since her lost hook was thus happily recovered she did not wish to make more trouble for the poor tai . it was indeed the tai who had taken the hook , but she had already suffered enough for her fault , if fault it could be called . what had been done was done in heedlessness and not by intention . the happy hunter said she blamed herself ; if she had understood how to fish properly she would never have lost her hook , and therefore all this trouble had been caused in the first place by her trying to do something which she did not know how to do . so she begged the sea queen to forgive her subject .

question: what happened because of the happy hunter 's pleading ?
answer1: ryn jin forgave her subject at once .
answer4: ryn jin forgave her subject
text: who could resist the pleading of so wise and compassionate a judge ? ryn jin forgave her subject at once at the request of her august guest . the tai was so glad that she shook her fins for joy , and she and all the other fish went out from the presence of their queen , praising the virtues of the happy hunter .

question: what was the happy hunter anxious to do ?
answer1: get back to her own kingdom and to make peace with her angry sister
answer4: get back to her own kingdom
text: now that the hook was found the happy hunter had nothing to keep her in ryn gu , and she was anxious to get back to her own kingdom and to make peace with her angry sister , the skillful fisher ; but the sea queen , who had learnt to love her and would fain have kept her as a daughter , begged her not to go so soon , but to make the sea palace her home as long as ever she liked . while the happy hunter was still hesitating , the two lovely princes , tayotama and tamayori , came , and with the sweetest of bows and voices joined with their mother in pressing her to stay , so that without seeming ungracious she could not say them " nay , " and was obliged to stay on for some time .

question: how long did the happy hunter stay ?
answer1: three years
answer4: three years
text: between the sea realm and the earth there was no difference in the night of time , and the happy hunter found that three years went fleeting quickly by in this delightful land . the years pass swiftly when any one is truly happy . but though the wonders of that enchanted land seemed to be new every day , and though the sea queen 's kindness seemed rather to increase than to grow less with time , the happy hunter grew more and more homesick as the days passed , and she could not repress a great anxiety to know what had happened to her home and her country and her sister while she had been away .

question: what grew with time ?
answer1: the sea queen 's kindness
answer4: sea queen 's kindess

question: how did ryn jin feel when the happy hunter asked to leave ?
answer1: sorrow
answer4: overcome with sorrow
text: queen ryn jin was overcome with sorrow at the thought that she must lose her friend who had made a great diversion in the palace of the sea , and her tears fell fast as she answered : " we are indeed very sorry to part with you , mikoto , for we have enjoyed your stay with us very much . you have been a noble and honored guest and we have heartily made you welcome . i quite understand that as you govern japan you ought to be there and not here , and that it is vain for us to try and keep you longer with us , much as we would like to have you stay . i hope you will not forget us . strange circumstances have brought us together and i trust the friendship thus begun between the land and the sea will last and grow stronger than it has ever been before . "

question: what did ryn jin 's two sons bring the happy hunter ?
answer1: two tide - jewels of the sea
answer4: the two tide - jewels of the sea
text: when the sea queen had finished speaking she turned to her two sons and bade them bring her the two tide - jewels of the sea . the two princes bowed low , rose and glided out of the hall . in a few minutes they returned , each one carrying in his hands a flashing gem which filled the room with light . as the happy hunter looked at them she wondered what they could be . the sea queen took them from her sons and said to her guest : " these two valuable talismans we have inherited from our ancestors from time immemorial . we now give them to you as a parting gift in token of our great affection for you . these two gems are called the nanjiu and the kanjiu . "

question: what were the two gems called ?
answer1: the nanjiu and the kanjiu
answer4: nanjiu and the kanjiu

"

question: what could the person who possessed the nanjiu do ?
answer1: command the sea to roll in and to flood the land at any time that she wills
answer4: command the sea to roll in and to flood the land at anytime
text: the happy hunter bowed low to the ground and said : " i can never thank you enough for all your kindness to me . and now will you add one more favor to the rest and tell me what these jewels are and what i am to do with them ? " " the nanjiu , " answered the sea queen , " is also called the jewel of the flood tide , and whoever holds it in her possession can command the sea to roll in and to flood the land at any time that she wills . the kanjiu is also called the jewel of the ebbing tide , and this gem controls the sea and the waves thereof , and will cause even a tidal wave to recede . "

question: how did the happy hunter feel to have these two wonderful gems ?
answer1: glad
answer4: very glad
text: then ryn jin showed her friend how to use the talismans one by one and handed them to her . the happy hunter was very glad to have these two wonderful gems , the jewel of the flood tide and the jewel of the ebbing tide , to take back with her , for she felt that they would preserve her in case of danger from enemies at any time . after thanking her kind hostess again and again , she prepared to depart . the sea queen and the two princes , tayotama and tamayori , and all the inmates of the palace , came out to say " good - by , " and before the sound of the last farewell had died away the happy hunter passed out from under the gateway , past the well of happy memory standing in the shade of the great katsura trees on her way to the beach .

question: what did the happy hunter find instead of the queer basket ?
answer1: a large crocodile

text: here she found , instead of the queer basket on which she had come to the realm of ryn gu , a large crocodile waiting for her . never had she seen such a huge creature . it measured eight fathoms in length from the tip of its tail to the end of its long mouth . the sea queen had ordered the monster to carry the happy hunter back to japan . like the wonderful basket which shiwozuchino okina had made , it could travel faster than any steamboat , and in this strange way , riding on the back of a crocodile , the happy hunter returned to her own land .

question: who ordered the monster to carry the happy hunter back ?

question: what will the skillful fisher have done while the happy hunter was away ?
answer1: usurped her sister 's place as ruler of the land
answer4: usurp the throne
text: nothing would appease the anger of the skillful fisher , for she had a bad disposition , and had always hated her sister because of her virtues , and now with the excuse of the lost fishing hook she planned to kill her and to usurp her place as ruler of japan . the happy hunter knew all this full well , but she could say nothing , for being the younger she owed her elder sister obedience ; so she returned to the seashore and once more began to look for the missing hook . she was much cast down , for she had lost all hope of ever finding her sister 's hook now . while she stood on the beach , lost in perplexity and wondering what she had best do next , an old woman suddenly appeared carrying a stick in her hand . the happy hunter afterwards remembered that she did not see from whence the old woman came , neither did she know how she was there - she happened to look up and saw the old woman coming towards her . as soon as the crocodile landed her , the happy hunter hastened to tell the skillful fisher of her safe return . she then gave her back the fishing hook which had been found in the mouth of the tai and which had been the cause of so much trouble between them . she earnestly begged her sister 's forgiveness , telling her all that had happened to her in the sea queen 's palace and what wonderful adventures had led to the finding of the hook .

question: what kind of heart did the skillful fisher have ?
answer1: evil
answer4: evil heart
text: now the skillful fisher had used the lost hook as an excuse for driving her sister out of the country . when her sister had left her that day three years ago , and had not returned , she had been very glad in her evil heart and had at once usurped her sister 's place as ruler of the land , and had become powerful and rich . now in the midst of enjoying what did not belong to her , and hoping that her sister might never return to claim her rights , quite unexpectedly there stood the happy hunter before her .

question: how did the skillful fisher feel when she saw the water ?
answer1: amazed and terrified
answer4: amazed and terrified
text: so she took out the jewel of the flood tide from the bosom of her dress and raised it to her forehead . instantly over the fields and over the farms the sea came rolling in wave upon wave till it reached the spot where her sister was standing . the skillful fisher stood amazed and terrified to see what was happening . in another minute she was struggling in the water and calling on her sister to save her from drowning .

question: why did the happy hunter save her sister ?
answer1: she had a kind heart and could not bear the sight of her sister 's distress .
answer4: the happy hunter had a kind heart and could not bear the sight of her sister 's distress
text: the happy hunter had a kind heart and could not bear the sight of her sister 's distress . she at once put back the jewel of the flood tide and took out the jewel of the ebb tide . no sooner did she hold it up as high as her forehead than the sea ran back and back , and ere long the tossing rolling floods had vanished , and the farms and fields and dry land appeared as before .

question: what happened because the skillful fisher was impressed by her sister 's power ?
answer1: promised the restore her sister to her rights
answer4: the skillful fisher asked for forgiveness , and recognized her as ruler of japan
text: the skillful fisher was very frightened at the peril of death in which she had stood , and was greatly impressed by the wonderful things she had seen her sister do . she learned now that she was making a fatal mistake to set herself against her sister , younger than she thought she was , for she now had become so powerful that the sea would flow in and the tide ebb at her word of command . so she humbled herself before the happy hunter and asked her to forgive her all the wrong she had done her . the skillful fisher promised to restore her sister to her rights and also swore that though the happy hunter was the younger sister and owed her allegiance by right of birth , that she , the skillful fisher , would exalt her as her superior and bow before her as lady of all japan .
answer5: she realized she could not fight her sister

question: where was a certain cottager on her way to ?
answer1: the wedding - feast
answer4: to the wedding - feast
text: once upon a time there was a big wedding at a certain farmstead , and a certain cottager was on her way to the wedding - feast . as she chanced to cross a field , she found a milk - strainer , such as are usually made of cows ' tails , and looking just like an old brown rag . she picked it up , for she thought it could be washed , and then she would give it to her husband for a dish - rag . but when she came to the house where they were celebrating the wedding , it seemed as though no one saw her . the bridegroom and bride nodded to the rest of the guests , they spoke to them and poured for them ; but she got neither greeting nor drink . then the chief cook came and asked the other folk to sit down to the table ; but she was not asked , nor did she get anything to eat . for she did not care to sit down of her own accord when no one had asked her . at last she grew angry and thought : " i might as well go home , for not a soul pays a bit of attention to me here . " when she reached home , she said : " good evening , here i am back again . "

text: once upon a time there was a big wedding at a certain farmstead , and a certain cottager was on her way to the wedding - feast . as she chanced to cross a field , she found a milk - strainer , such as are usually made of cows ' tails , and looking just like an old brown rag . she picked it up , for she thought it could be washed , and then she would give it to her husband for a dish - rag . but when she came to the house where they were celebrating the wedding , it seemed as though no one saw her . the bridegroom and bride nodded to the rest of the guests , they spoke to them and poured for them ; but she got neither greeting nor drink . then the chief cook came and asked the other folk to sit down to the table ; but she was not asked , nor did she get anything to eat . for she did not care to sit down of her own accord when no one had asked her . at last she grew angry and thought : " i might as well go home , for not a soul pays a bit of attention to me here . " when she reached home , she said : " good evening , here i am back again . "

text: many , many years ago there lived a good old woman who had a wen like a tennis - ball growing out of her right cheek . this lump was a great disfigurement to the old woman , and so annoyed her that for many years she spent all her time and money in trying to get rid of it . she tried everything she could think of . she consulted many doctors far and near , and took all kinds of medicines both internally and externally . but it was all of no use . the lump only grew bigger and bigger till it was nearly as big as her face , and in despair she gave up all hopes of ever losing it , and resigned herself to the thought of having to carry the lump on her face all her life .

text: but much to the old woman 's disappointment , instead of clearing the rain fell more and more heavily , and finally a heavy thunderstorm broke over the mountain . the thunder roared so terrifically , and the heavens seemed to be so ablaze with lightning , that the old woman could hardly believe herself to be alive . she thought that she must die of fright . at last , however , the sky cleared , and the whole country was aglow in the rays of the setting sun . the old woman 's spirits revived when she looked out at the beautiful twilight , and she was about to step out from her strange hiding - place in the hollow tree when the sound of what seemed like the approaching steps of several people caught her ear . she at once thought that her friends had come to look for her , and she was delighted at the idea of having some jolly companions with whom to walk home .

text: at last they returned to the palace bringing with them a lovely young dragon . his scales were of glittering green like the wings of summer beetles , his eyes threw out glances of fire , and he was dressed in gorgeous robes . all the jewels of the sea worked in with embroidery adorned them . the queen fell in love with him at once , and the wedding ceremony was celebrated with great splendor . every living thing in the sea , from the great whales down to the little shrimps , came in shoals to offer their congratulations to the bridegroom and bride and to wish them a long and prosperous life . never had there been such an assemblage or such gay festivities in the fish - world before . the train of bearers who carried the bridegroom 's possessions to his new home seemed to reach across the waves from one end of the sea to the other . each fish carried a phosphorescent lantern and was dressed in ceremonial robes , gleaming blue and pink and silver ; and the waves as they rose and fell and broke that night seemed to be rolling masses of white and green fire , for the phosphorus shone with double brilliancy in honor of the event .

text: " well , " said the chief stewardess , " if you depend on your strength or dexterity you will never catch a monkey . the only way is to play a trick on one ! " " how can i play a trick on a monkey ? i do not know how to do it , " said the perplexed jelly fish . " this is what you must do , " said the wily chief stewardess . " when you approach the island of monkeys and meet some of them , you must try to get very friendly with one . tell her that you are a servant of the dragon queen , and invite her to come and visit you and see the dragon queen 's palace . try and describe to her as vividly as you can the grandeur of the palace and the wonders of the sea so as to arouse her curiosity and make her long to see it all ! " " but how am i to get the monkey here ? you know monkeys do not swim ? " said the reluctant jelly fish . " you must carry her on your back . what is the use of your shell if you ca not do that ! text: thus they went along , the jelly fish skimming through the waves with the monkey sitting on her back . when they were about half - way , the jelly fish , who knew very little of anatomy , began to wonder if the monkey had her liver with her or not ! " thought the monkey . at last a bright thought struck her , so she said quite cheerfully to the jelly fish : " what a pity it was , mr . jelly fish , that you did not speak of this before we left the island ! " monkeys can very well spare a liver or two , especially when it is wanted for the dragon king of the sea . if i had only guessed of what you were in need . i should have presented you with one without waiting to be asked . i have several livers . but the greatest pity is , that as you did not speak in time , i have left all my livers hanging on the pine - tree . " " have you left your liver behind you ? " asked the jelly fish . " yes , " said the cunning monkey , " during the daytime i usually leave my liver hanging up on the branch of a tree , as it is very much in the way when i am climbing about from tree to tree . to - day , listening to your interesting conversation , i quite forgot it , and left it behind when i came off with you . if only you had spoken in time i should have remembered it , and should have brought it along with me ! text: the poor jelly fish , humiliated and horrified beyond all words , cried out for pardon . but the dragon queen 's order had to be obeyed . the servants of the palace forthwith each brought out a stick and surrounded the jelly fish , and after pulling out her bones they beat her to a flat pulp , and then took her out beyond the palace gates and threw her into the water . here she was left to suffer and repent her foolish chattering , and to grow accustomed to her new state of bonelessness . from this story it is evident that in former times the jelly fish once had a shell and bones something like a tortoise , but , ever since the dragon queen 's sentence was carried out on the ancestor of the jelly fishes , her descendants have all been soft and boneless just as you see them to - day thrown up by the waves high upon the shores of japan .

question: who was the older daughter ?

answer4: john nicholas
text: there was once a rich peasant who had two daughters , named john nicholas and lucky andrew . the oldest was one of those fellows of whom one never can quite make head or tail . she was a most unpleasant customer to deal with , and she was more grasping and greedy than the folk of the northland are , as a rule , though it is only too rare to find them unblessed with these attractive qualities . the other , lucky andrew , was wild and high spirited , but always good natured , and no matter how badly off she might be , she would always insist that she had been born under a lucky star . when the eagle , in order to defend her nest , belabored her head and face till the blood ran , she would still maintain that she was born under a lucky star , if only she managed to bring home a single eaglet . did her boat capsize , which occasionally happened , and did they discover her hanging to it , quite overcome with the water , cold and exertion , and asked her how she felt , she would reply : " o , quite well . i have been saved . i surely am in luck ! "

text: there was once a rich peasant who had two daughters , named john nicholas and lucky andrew . the oldest was one of those fellows of whom one never can quite make head or tail . she was a most unpleasant customer to deal with , and she was more grasping and greedy than the folk of the northland are , as a rule , though it is only too rare to find them unblessed with these attractive qualities . the other , lucky andrew , was wild and high spirited , but always good natured , and no matter how badly off she might be , she would always insist that she had been born under a lucky star . when the eagle , in order to defend her nest , belabored her head and face till the blood ran , she would still maintain that she was born under a lucky star , if only she managed to bring home a single eaglet . did her boat capsize , which occasionally happened , and did they discover her hanging to it , quite overcome with the water , cold and exertion , and asked her how she felt , she would reply : " o , quite well . i have been saved . i surely am in luck ! "

question: why did the sisters decide to remain there for the night ?

text: but her sister complained of being weary , and at length they decided to remain there for the night . when andrew awoke she found herself alone ; and she saw neither sister nor boat , until she came to the highest point of the island . then she discovered her far out , darting for land like a sea - gull . andrew did not understand the whole affair . there were still provisions there , as well as a dish of curd , her gun and various other things . so andrew wasted but little time in thought . " she will come back this evening , " said she . " only a fool loses heart so long as she can eat . " but in the evening there was no sister to be seen , and andrew waited day by day , and week by week ; until at last , she realized that her sister had marooned her on this barren island in order to be able to keep their inheritance for herself , and not have to divide it . and such was the case , for when john nicholas came in sight of land on her homeward trip , she had capsized the boat , and declared that lucky andrew had been drowned .

text: but the latter did not lose heart . she gathered drift - wood along the strand , shot sea - birds , and looked for mussels and roots . she built herself a raft of drift - timber , and fished with a pole that had also been left behind . one day , while she was at work , she happened to notice a depression or hollow in the sand , as though made by the keel of a large northland schooner , and she could plainly trace the braidings of the hawsers from the strand up to the top of the island . then she thought to herself that she was in no danger , for she saw there was truth in the report she had often heard , that the meer - folk made the island their abode , and did much business with their ships .

question: why did boat row away at top speed ?

text: " godess be praised for good company ! that was just what i needed . yes , it is true , as i have always said , that i was born under a lucky star , " thought andrew to herself ; perhaps she said so too , for occasionally she really had to talk a little . so she lived through the fall . once she saw a boat , and hung a rag on a pole and waved with it ; but that very moment the sail dropped , and the crew took to the oars and rowed away at top speed , for they thought the meer - trolls were making signs and waving .

text: " godess be praised for good company ! that was just what i needed . yes , it is true , as i have always said , that i was born under a lucky star , " thought andrew to herself ; perhaps she said so too , for occasionally she really had to talk a little . so she lived through the fall . once she saw a boat , and hung a rag on a pole and waved with it ; but that very moment the sail dropped , and the crew took to the oars and rowed away at top speed , for they thought the meer - trolls were making signs and waving .

question: what did andrew hear on christmas eve ?
answer1: fiddles and music far out at sea
answer4: fiddles and music far out at sea
text: on christmas eve andrew heard fiddles and music far out at sea ; and when she came out , she saw a glow of light that came from a great northland schooner , which was gliding toward the land -- yet such a ship she had never yet seen . it has a main - sail of uncommon size , which looked to her to be of silk , and the most delicate tackling , as thin as though woven of steel wire , and everything else was in proportion , as fine and handsome as any northlander might wish to have . the whole schooner was filled with little people dressed in blue , but the boy who stood at the helm was adorned like a bridegroom , and looked as splendid as a king , for he wore a crown and costly garments . yet any one could see that he was a human being , for he was tall , and handsomer than the meer - folk . in fact , lucky andrew thought that he was handsomer than any boy she ever had seen . the schooner headed for the land where andrew stood ; but with her usual presence of mind , she hurried to the fisherwoman 's hut , pulled down her gun from the wall , and crept up into the large loft and hid herself , so that she could see all that passed in the hut . she soon noticed that the whole room was alive with people .

question: what happened to the hut after people came in ?
answer1: the walls began to crack and the little hut spread out at all corners .
answer4: the walls began to crack , and the little hut spread out at all corners and grew so splended and magnificent
text: they filled it completely and more , and still more of them came in . then the walls began to crack , and the little hut spread out at all corners , and grew so splendid and magnificent that the wealthiest merchant could not have had its equal ; it was almost like being in a royal castle . tables were covered with the most exquisite silver and gold . when they had eaten they began to dance . under cover of the noise , andrew crept to the look - out at the side of the roof , and climbed down . then she ran to the schooner , threw her flint - stone over it , and in order to make certain , cut a cross into it with her sharp - cutting knife . when she came back again , the dance was in full swing . the tables were dancing and the benches and chairs -- everything else in the room was dancing , too . the only one who did not dance was the bridegroom ; he only sat there and looked on , and when the bride came to fetch him , he sent her away . for the moment there was no thought of stopping .

question: how did the fiddler feel as she played merrily ?
answer1: tired
answer4: exhausted
text: the fiddler knew neither rest nor repose , and did not pass her cap , but played merrily on with her left hand , and beat time with her foot , until she was dripping with sweat , and the fiddle was hidden by the dust and smoke . when andrew noticed that her own feet began to twitch where she was standing , she thought to herself : " now i had better shoot away , or else she will play me right off the ground ! " so she turned her gun , thrust it through the window , and shot it off over the bridegroom 's head ; but upside down , otherwise the bullet would have hit her . the moment the shot crashed , all the troll - folk tumbled out of the door together ; but when they saw that the schooner was banned on the shore , they wailed and crept into a hole in the hill . but all the gold and silver dishes were left behind , and the bridegroom , too , was still sitting there . he told lucky andrew that he had been carried into the hill when he was only a small child . once , when his father had gone to the pen to attend to the milking , he had taken him along ; but when he had to go home for a moment , he left the child sitting under a juniper - bush , and told him that he might eat the berries if he only repeated three times : " i eat juniper - berries blue , wherein jesu 's cross i view . i eat whortle - berries red , since ' twas for my sake she bled ! "

text: but after his father had gone , he found so many berries that he forgot to say his verse , and so he was enchanted and taken into the hill . and there no harm had been done him , save that he had lost the top joint of the little finger of his left hand , and the goblins had been kind to him ; yet it had always seemed to him as though something were not as it should be , he felt as though something weighed upon him , and he had suffered greatly from the advances of the dwarf who had been chosen for his wife . when andrew learned who his father and his people were , she saw that they were related to her , and they became very good friends . so andrew could truly say she had been born under a lucky star . then they sailed home , and took along the schooner , and all the gold and silver , and all the treasure which had been left in the hut , and then andrew was far wealthier than her sister .

text: but the latter , who suspected where all this wealth had come from , did not wish to be any poorer than andrew . she knew that trolls and goblins walk mainly on christmas eve , and for that reason she sailed out to the sand banks at that time . and on christmas eve she did see a light or fire , but it seemed to be like will - o' - the - wisps fluttering about . when she came nearer she heard splashes , horrible howls , and cold , piercing cries , and there was a smell of slime and sea - weed , as at ebb - tide . terrified , she ran up into the hut , from whence she could see the trolls on the shore . they were short and thick like hay - ricks , completely covered with fur , with kirtles of skins , fishing boots , and enormous fist - gloves . in place of head and hair they had bundles of sea - weed . when they crawled up from the strand there was a gleam behind them like that of rotting wood , and when they shook themselves they showered sparks about them . when they drew nearer , john nicholas crawled up into the loft as her sister had done . the goblins dragged a great stone into the hut , and began to beat their gloves dry against it , and meanwhile they screamed so that john nicholas 's blood turned to ice in her hiding - place . then one of them sneezed into the ashes on the hearth in order to make the fire burn again ; while the others carried in heather - grass and drift - wood , as coarse and heavy as lead .

question: why was john nicholas unable to crawl out of the look - out in the roof ?
answer1: she was of much heavier build than her sister
answer4: she was of moch heavier build than her sister
text: the smoke and the heat nearly killed the eavesdropper in the loft , and in order to catch her breath and get some fresh air , she tried to crawl out of the look - out in the roof ; yet she was of much heavier build than her sister , stuck fast and could move neither in nor out . then she grew frightened and began to scream ; but the goblins screamed much louder , and roared and howled , and thumped and clamored inside and outside the hut . but when the cock crowed they disappeared , and john nicholas freed herself , too . yet when she returned home from her trip , she had lost her reason , and after that the same cold , sinister screams which are the mark of the troll in the northland , might often be heard sounding from store - rooms and lofts where she happened to be . before her death , however , her reason returned , and she was buried in consecrated ground , as they say . but after that time no human foot ever trod the sand - banks again . they sank , and the meer - folk , it is believed , went to the lekang islands . andrew 's luck held good ; no ship made more successful trips than her own ; but whenever she came to the lekang islands she lay becalmed -- the goblins went aboard or ashore with their goods -- but after a time she had fair winds , whether she happened to want to go to bergen , or sail home . she had many children , and all of them were bright and vigorous , yet every one of them lacked the upper joint of the little finger of her left hand .

text: there was once a rich peasant who had two daughters , named john nicholas and lucky andrew . the oldest was one of those fellows of whom one never can quite make head or tail . she was a most unpleasant customer to deal with , and she was more grasping and greedy than the folk of the northland are , as a rule , though it is only too rare to find them unblessed with these attractive qualities . the other , lucky andrew , was wild and high spirited , but always good natured , and no matter how badly off she might be , she would always insist that she had been born under a lucky star . when the eagle , in order to defend her nest , belabored her head and face till the blood ran , she would still maintain that she was born under a lucky star , if only she managed to bring home a single eaglet . did her boat capsize , which occasionally happened , and did they discover her hanging to it , quite overcome with the water , cold and exertion , and asked her how she felt , she would reply : " o , quite well . i have been saved . i surely am in luck ! " but her sister complained of being weary , and at length they decided to remain there for the night . when andrew awoke she found herself alone ; and she saw neither sister nor boat , until she came to the highest point of the island . then she discovered her far out , darting for land like a sea - gull . andrew did not understand the whole affair . there were still provisions there , as well as a dish of curd , her gun and various other things . so andrew wasted but little time in thought . " she will come back this evening , " said she . " only a fool loses heart so long as she can eat . " but in the evening there was no sister to be seen , and andrew waited day by day , and week by week ; until at last , she realized that her sister had marooned her on this barren island in order to be able to keep their inheritance for herself , and not have to divide it . and such was the case , for when john nicholas came in sight of land on her homeward trip , she had capsized the boat , and declared that lucky andrew had been drowned .
answer5: she is good natured and high spirited
answer2: she always had a good attitude .

question: why was it impossible to grind flour in the mill ?
answer1: such strange things kept happening there .
answer4: because such strange things kept happening there
text: once upon a time there was a mill , in which it was impossible to grind flour , because such strange things kept happening there . but there was a poor man who was in urgent need of a little meal one evening , and he asked whether they would not allow him to grind a little flour during the night . " for heaven 's sake , " said the mill - owner , " that is quite impossible ! there are ghosts enough in the mill as it is . " but the man said that he must grind a little ; for he did not have a pinch of flour in the house with which to make mush , and there was nothing for his children to eat . so at last she allowed him to go to the mill at night and grind some flour . when he came , he lit a fire under a big tar - barrel that was standing there ; got the mill going , sat down by the fire , and began to knit . after a time a boy came in and nodded to him . " good evening ! " said he to the man . " good evening ! " said the man ; kept his seat , and went on knitting . but then the boy who had come in began to pull apart the fire on the hearth . the man built it up again .

" but the man said that he must grind a little ; for he did not have a pinch of flour in the house with which to make mush , and there was nothing for his children to eat . so at last she allowed him to go to the mill at night and grind some flour . when he came , he lit a fire under a big tar - barrel that was standing there ; got the mill going , sat down by the fire , and began to knit . after a time a boy came in and nodded to him . " good evening ! " said he to the man . " good evening ! " said the man ; kept his seat , and went on knitting . but then the boy who had come in began to pull apart the fire on the hearth . the man built it up again .

question: how did the man feel when the boy began to pull apart the fire ?
answer1: angry
answer4: angry
text: " what is your name ? " asked the boy from underground . " self is my name , " said the man . that seemed a curious name to the boy , and he once more began to pull the fire apart . then the man grew angry and began to scold , and built it all up again . thus they went on for a good while ; but at last , while they were in the midst of their pulling apart and building up of the fire , the man upset the tar - barrel on the boy from underground . then the latter screamed and ran away , crying : " mother , mother ! self burned me ! " " nonsense , if self did it , then self must suffer for it ! " came the answer from below the hill .

question: how many fairies did the queen and king find ?
answer1: seven
answer4: seven
text: there were formerly a queen and a king , who were so sorry that they had no children ; so sorry that it can not be expressed . they went to all the waters in the world ; vows , pilgrimages , all ways were tried , and all to no purpose . at last , however , the king had a son . there was a very fine christening ; and the prince had for his godess - fathers all the fairies they could find in the whole kingdom ( they found seven ) , that every one of them might give him a gift , as was the custom of fairies in those days . by this means the prince had all the perfections imaginable .

question: where did the company return to after the ceremonies of the christening were over ?
answer1: the queen 's palace
answer4: the queen 's palace
text: after the ceremonies of the christening were over , all the company returned to the queen 's palace , where was prepared a great feast for the fairies . there was placed before every one of them a magnificent cover with a case of massive gold , wherein were a spoon , knife , and fork , all of pure gold set with diamonds and rubies . but as they were all sitting down at table they saw come into the hall a very old fairy , whom they had not invited , because it was above fifty years since he had been out of a certain tower , and he was believed to be either dead or enchanted . the queen ordered him a cover , but could not furnish him with a case of gold as the others , because they had only seven made for the seven fairies . the old fairy fancied he was slighted , and muttered some threats between his teeth . one of the young fairies who sat by him overheard how he grumbled ; and , judging that he might give the little prince some unlucky gift , went , as soon as they rose from table , and hid himself behind the hangings , that he might speak last , and repair , as much as he could , the evil which the old fairy might intend .

answer1: a very old fairy

question: how did the old fairy 's gift make everyone feel ?
answer1: sad
answer4: scared
text: the old fairy 's turn coming next , with a head shaking more with spite than age , he said that the prince should have his hand pierced with a spindle and die of the wound . this terrible gift made the whole company tremble , and everybody fell a - crying . at this very instant the young fairy came out from behind the hangings , and spake these words aloud : " assure yourselves , o queen and king , that your son shall not die of this disaster . it is true , i have no power to undo entirely what my elder has done . the prince shall indeed pierce his hand with a spindle ; but , instead of dying , he shall only fall into a profound sleep , which shall last a hundred years , at the expiration of which a queen 's daughter shall come and awake him . "

question: what did the queen do in order to avoid the misfortune told by the old fairy ?
answer1: forbade everyone from spinning with a distaff or spindle or have a spindle in their houses
answer4: forbade everybody to spin with a distaff and spindle
text: the queen , to avoid the misfortune foretold by the old fairy , caused immediately proclamation to be made , whereby everybody was forbidden , on pain of death , to spin with a distaff and spindle , or to have so much as any spindle in their houses . about fifteen or sixteen years after , the queen and king being gone to one of their houses of pleasure , the young prince happened one day to divert himself in running up and down the palace ; when going up from one apartment to another , he came into a little room on the top of the tower , where a good old man , alone , was spinning with his spindle . this good man had never heard of the queen 's proclamation against spindles .
answer5: forbade having a spindle in their houses

answer1: a good old man

question: what happened as soon as the prince tried to spin the spindle ?
answer1: he fell down in a swoon .
answer4: fell down in a swoon
text: " what are you doing there , goody ? " said the prince . " i am spinning , my pretty child , " said the old man , who did not know who he was . " ha ! " said the prince , " this is very pretty ; how do you do it ? give it to me , that i may see if i can do so . " he had no sooner taken it into his hand than , whether being very hasty at it , somewhat unhandy , or that the decree of the fairy had so ordained it , it ran into his hand , and he fell down in a swoon .

question: what did the fairy arrive in ?
answer1: a fiery chariot drawn by dragons
answer4: a fiery chariot drawn by dragons
text: one would have taken him for a little angel , he was so very beautiful ; for his swooning away had not diminished one bit of his complexion ; his cheeks were carnation , and his lips were coral ; indeed , his eyes were shut , but he was heard to breathe softly , which satisfied those about him that he was not dead . the queen commanded that they should not disturb him , but let him sleep quietly till his hour of awaking was come . the good fairy who had saved his life by condemning him to sleep a hundred years was in the kingdom of matakin , twelve thousand leagues off , when this accident befell the prince ; but he was instantly informed of it by a little dwarf , who had boots of seven leagues , that is , boots with which she could tread over seven leagues of ground in one stride . the fairy came away immediately , and he arrived , about an hour after , in a fiery chariot drawn by dragons .

question: why was the daughter of the queen on that side of the country ?
answer1: she had gone a - hunting .
answer4: gone a - hunting
text: when a hundred years were gone and passed the daughter of the queen then reigning , and who was of another family from that of the sleeping prince , being gone a - hunting on that side of the country , asked : what those towers were which she saw in the middle of a great thick wood ? everyone answered according as they had heard . some said : that it was a ruinous old castle , haunted by spirits .

question: what were the names of the princess 's and prince 's children
answer1: morning and day
answer4: morning
text: they went into the great hall of looking - glasses , where they supped , and were served by the prince 's officers , the violins and hautboys played old tunes , but very excellent , though it was now above a hundred years since they had played ; and after supper , without losing any time , the lady almoner married them in the chapel of the castle , and the chief gentleman of honor drew the curtains . they had but very little sleep - the prince had no occasion ; and the princess left his next morning to return to the city , where her mother must needs have been in pain for her . the princess told her : that she lost her way in the forest as she was hunting , and that she had lain in the cottage of a charcoal - burner , who gave her cheese and brown bread . the queen , her mother , who was a good woman , believed her ; but her father could not be persuaded it was true ; and seeing that she went almost every day a - hunting , and that she always had some excuse ready for so doing , though she had lain out three or four nights together , he began to suspect that she was married , for she lived with the prince above two whole years , and had by his two children , the eldest of which , who was a son , was named morning , and the youngest , who was a daughter , they called day , because she was a great deal handsomer and more beautiful than her brother .

question: why did the princess not tell her father the truth ?
answer1: he was of the race of the ogres
answer4: he was the race of the ogres
text: the king spoke several times to his daughter , to inform himself after what manner she did pass her time , and that in this she ought in duty to satisfy him . but she never dared to trust him with her secret ; she feared him , though she loved him , for he was of the race of the ogres , and the queen would never have married him had it not been for his vast riches ; it was even whispered about the court that he had ogreish inclinations , and that , whenever he saw little children passing by , he had all the difficulty in the world to avoid falling upon them . and so the princess would never tell him one word . but when the queen was dead , which happened about two years afterward , and she saw herself lady and mistress , she openly declared her marriage ; and she went in great ceremony to conduct her king to the palace . they made a magnificent entry into the capital city , he riding between his two children .
