question: what did people believe the tower in the middle of the great thick wood was ?
answer1: ruinous old castle haunted by spirits
answer4: ruinous old castle haunted by spirits
text: when a hundred years were gone and passed the daughter of the queen then reigning , and who was of another family from that of the sleeping prince , being gone a - hunting on that side of the country , asked : what those towers were which she saw in the middle of a great thick wood ? everyone answered according as they had heard . some said : that it was a ruinous old castle , haunted by spirits . others , that all the sorceresses and wizards of the country kept there their sabbath or night 's meeting . the common opinion was : that an ogre lived there , and that she carried thither all the little children she could catch , that she might eat them up at her leisure , without anybody being able to follow her , as having herself only the power to pass through the wood . the princess was at a stand , not knowing what to believe , when a very good countryman spake to her thus : " may it please your royal highness , it is now about fifty years since i heard from my mother , who heard my grandmother say , that there was then in this castle a prince , the most beautiful was ever seen ; that he must sleep there a hundred years , and should be waked by a queen 's daughter , for whom he was reserved . " the young princess was all on fire at these words , believing , without weighing the matter , that she could put an end to this rare adventure ; and , pushed on by love and honor , resolved that moment to look into it .
answer2: all the sorceresses and wizards of the country kept there their sabbath or night 's meeting .

question: why did the natives call the immense boulder the dwarfie stone ?
answer1: snorro the dwarf lived there .
answer4: snorro the dwarf lived there
text: far up in a green valley in the island of hoy stands an immense boulder . it is hollow inside , and the natives of these northern islands call it the dwarfie stone , because long centuries ago , so the legend has it , snorro the dwarf lived there . nobody knew where snorro came from , or how long she had dwelt in the dark chamber inside the dwarfie stone . all that they knew about her was that she was a little woman , with a queer , twisted , deformed body and a face of marvellous beauty , which never seemed to look any older , but was always smiling and young . women said that this was because snorro 's mother had been a fairy , and not a denizen of earth , who had bequeathed to her daughter the gift of perpetual youth , but nobody knew whether this were true or not , for the dwarf had inhabited the dwarfie stone long before the oldest woman or man in hoy had been born . one thing was certain , however : she had inherited from her father , whom all women agreed had been mortal , the dangerous qualities of vanity and ambition . and the longer she lived the more vain and ambitious did she become , until at last she always carried a mirror of polished steel round her neck , into which she constantly looked in order to see the reflection of her hand some face .

text: far up in a green valley in the island of hoy stands an immense boulder . it is hollow inside , and the natives of these northern islands call it the dwarfie stone , because long centuries ago , so the legend has it , snorro the dwarf lived there . nobody knew where snorro came from , or how long she had dwelt in the dark chamber inside the dwarfie stone . all that they knew about her was that she was a little woman , with a queer , twisted , deformed body and a face of marvellous beauty , which never seemed to look any older , but was always smiling and young . women said that this was because snorro 's mother had been a fairy , and not a denizen of earth , who had bequeathed to her daughter the gift of perpetual youth , but nobody knew whether this were true or not , for the dwarf had inhabited the dwarfie stone long before the oldest woman or man in hoy had been born . one thing was certain , however : she had inherited from her father , whom all women agreed had been mortal , the dangerous qualities of vanity and ambition . and the longer she lived the more vain and ambitious did she become , until at last she always carried a mirror of polished steel round her neck , into which she constantly looked in order to see the reflection of her hand some face .

question: who came to seek snorro 's help ?
answer1: the country people
answer4: the country people
text: and she would not attend to the country people who came to seek her help , unless they bowed themselves humbly before her and spoke to her as if she were a queen . i say that the country people sought her help , for she spent her time , or appeared to spend it , in collecting herbs and simples on the hillsides , which she carried home with her to her dark abode , and distilled medicines and potions from them , which she sold to her neighbours at wondrous high prices . she was also the possessor of a wonderful leathern - covered book , clasped with clasps of brass , over which she would pore for hours together , and out of which she would tell the simple islanders their fortunes , if they would . for they feared the book almost as much as they feared snorro herself , for it was whispered that it had once belonged to odin , and they crossed themselves for protection as they named the mighty enchantress .

question: why did snorro choose to live in the dwarfie stone ?
answer1: she wanted to find a stone .
answer4: she wanted to find the carbuncle
text: but all the time they never guessed the real reason why snorro chose to live in the dwarfie stone . i will tell you why she did so . not very far from the stone there was a curious hill , shaped exactly like a wart . it was known as the wart hill of hoy , and women said that somewhere in the side of it was hidden a wonderful carbuncle , which , when it was found , would bestow on its finder marvellous magic gifts -- health , wealth , and happiness . everything , in fact , that a human being could desire . and the curious thing about this carbuncle was , that it was said that it could be seen at certain times , if only the people who were looking for it were at the right spot at the right moment . now snorro had made up her mind that she would find this wonderful stone , so , while she pretended to spend all her time in reading her great book or distilling medicines from her herbs , she was really keeping a keen look - out during her wanderings , noting every tuft of grass or piece of rock under which it might be hidden . and at night , when everyone else was asleep , she would creep out , with pickaxe and spade , to turn over the rocks or dig over the turf , in the hope of finding the long - sought - for treasure underneath them .
answer2: she was searching for a stone .

question: who lived in the cave along with snorro , and was her bosom friend and companion ?
answer1: an enormous grey - headed raven
answer4: an enourmous grey - headed raven
text: she was always accompanied on these occasions by an enormous grey - headed raven , who lived in the cave along with her , and who was her bosom friend and companion . the islanders feared this bird of ill omen as much , perhaps , as they feared its mistress ; for , although they went to consult snorro in all their difficulties and perplexities , and bought medicines and love - potions from her , they always looked upon her with a certain dread , feeling that there was something weird and uncanny about her . now , at the time we are speaking of , orkney was governed by two earls , who were half - sisters . paul , the elder , was a tall , handsome woman , with dark hair , and eyes like sloes . all the country people loved her , for she was so skilled in knightly exercises , and had such a sweet and loving nature , that no one could help being fond of her . old people 's eyes would brighten at the sight of her , and the little children would run out to greet her as she rode by their fathers ' doors . and this was the more remarkable because , with all her winning manner , she had such a lack of conversation that women called her paul the silent , or paul the taciturn .

question: who was as different from her sister as night is from day ?
answer1: harold
answer4: harold
text: harold , on the other hand , was as different from her sister as night is from day . she was fair - haired and blue - eyed , and she had gained for herself the name of harold the orator , because she was always free of speech and ready with her tongue . but for all this she was not a favourite . for she was haughty , and jealous , and quick - tempered , and the old folks ' eyes did not brighten at the sight of her , and the babes , instead of toddling out to greet her , hid their faces in their fathers ' skirts when they saw her coming . harold could not help knowing that the people liked her silent sister best , and the knowledge made her jealous of her , so a coldness sprang up between them . now it chanced , one summer , that earl harold went on a visit to the queen of scotland , accompanied by her father , the countess helga , and his brother , the countess fraukirk .

question: who was a charming young irish gentleman ?
answer1: the gentleman morna
answer4: the gentleman morna
text: and while she was at court she met a charming young irish gentleman , the gentleman morna , who had come from ireland to scotland to attend upon the scottish king . he was so sweet , and good , and gentle that earl harold 's heart was won , and she made up her mind that he , and only he , should be her bridegroom . but although she had paid his much attention , gentleman morna had sometimes caught glimpses of her jealous temper ; he had seen an evil expression in her eyes , and had heard her speak sharply to her servants , and he had no wish to marry her . so , to her great amazement , he refused the honour which she offered him , and told her that he would prefer to remain as he was . earl harold ground her teeth in silent rage , but she saw that it was no use pressing her suit at that moment . so what she could not obtain by her own merits she determined to obtain by guile . accordingly she begged her father to persuade the gentleman morna to go back with them on a visit , hoping that when he was alone with her in orkney , she would be able to overcome his prejudice against her , and induce him to become her husband . and all the while she never remembered her sister paul ; or , if she did , she never thought it possible that she could be her rival .

text: and while she was at court she met a charming young irish gentleman , the gentleman morna , who had come from ireland to scotland to attend upon the scottish king . he was so sweet , and good , and gentle that earl harold 's heart was won , and she made up her mind that he , and only he , should be her bridegroom . but although she had paid his much attention , gentleman morna had sometimes caught glimpses of her jealous temper ; he had seen an evil expression in her eyes , and had heard her speak sharply to her servants , and he had no wish to marry her . so , to her great amazement , he refused the honour which she offered him , and told her that he would prefer to remain as he was . earl harold ground her teeth in silent rage , but she saw that it was no use pressing her suit at that moment . so what she could not obtain by her own merits she determined to obtain by guile . accordingly she begged her father to persuade the gentleman morna to go back with them on a visit , hoping that when he was alone with her in orkney , she would be able to overcome his prejudice against her , and induce him to become her husband . and all the while she never remembered her sister paul ; or , if she did , she never thought it possible that she could be her rival .

" at these words harold 's vanity was flattered , and she thought that , after all , her step - sister was right , and that she had a very small chance , with her meagre gift of speech , of being successful in her suit . so she threw down her dagger , and , shaking hands with her , begged her to pardon her unkind thoughts , and went down the winding stair again in high good - humour with herself and all the world . by this time it was coming near to the feast of yule , and at that festival it was the custom for the earl and her court to leave kirkwall for some weeks , and go to the great palace of orphir , nine miles distant . and in order to see that everything was ready , earl paul took her departure some days before the others . the evening before she left she chanced to find the gentleman morna sitting alone in one of the deep windows of the great hall . he had been weeping , for he was full of sadness at the thought of her departure ; and at the sight of his distress the kind - hearted young earl could no longer contain herself , but , folding him in her arms , she whispered to him how much she loved him , and begged him to promise to be her husband .

" i have it , " she cried . answer4: countess fraukirk
text: " let us hold our peace till after yule , " he pleaded . " it will be a joy to keep our secret to ourselves for a little space ; there will be time enough then to let all the world know . " rather reluctantly , earl paul agreed ; and next day she set off for the palace at orphir , leaving her gentleman - love behind her . little she guessed the danger she was in ! for , all unknown to her , her step - uncle , countess fraukirk , had chanced to be in the hall , the evening before , hidden behind a curtain , and he had overheard every word that morna and she had spoken , and his heart was filled with black rage . for he was a hard , ambitious man , and he had always hated the young earl , who was no blood - relation to him , and who stood in the way of her sister , his own niece ; for , if paul were only dead , harold would be the sole earl of orkney . and now that she had stolen the heart of the gentleman morna , whom his own niece loved , his hate and anger knew no bounds . he had hastened off to his brother 's chamber as soon as the lovers had parted ; and there the two men had remained talking together till the chilly dawn broke in the sky .

" " thou knowest why i have taken up my abode in this lonely spot -- how i hope some day to light upon the magic carbuncle . thou knowest also how the people fear me , and hate me too , forsooth . and if the young earl died , and suspicion fell on me , i must needs fly the island , for my life would not be worth a grain of sand . then my chance of success would be gone . nay ! i can not do it , gentleman ; i can not do it . "

answer1: offer her much gold , and bribe her higher and higher
answer4: offer her gold
text: countess fraukirk ... hidden behind a curtain ... overheard every word . ] next day a boat went speeding over the narrow channel of water that separates pomona ( on the mainland ) from hoy . in it sat a man , but who he was , or what he was like , no one could say , for he was covered from head to foot with a black cloak , and his face was hidden behind a thick , dark veil . snorro the dwarf knew him , even before he laid aside his trappings , for countess fraukirk was no stranger to her . in the course of his long life he had often had occasion to seek her aid to help him in his evil deeds , and he had always paid her well for her services in yellow gold . she therefore welcomed him gladly ; but when she had heard the nature of his errand her smiling face grew grave again , and she shook her head . " i have served thee well , gentleman , in the past , " she said , " but methinks that this thing goeth beyond my courage . for to compass an earl 's death is a weighty matter , especially when she is so well beloved as is the earl paul . " " thou knowest why i have taken up my abode in this lonely spot -- how i hope some day to light upon the magic carbuncle . thou knowest also how the people fear me , and hate me too , forsooth . and if the young earl died , and suspicion fell on me , i must needs fly the island , for my life would not be worth a grain of sand . then my chance of success would be gone . nay ! i can not do it , gentleman ; i can not do it . " but the wily countess offered her much gold , and bribed her higher and higher , first with wealth , then with success , and lastly he promised to obtain for her a high post at the court of the queen of scotland ; and at that her ambition stirred within her , her determination gave way , and she consented to do what he asked . " i will summon my magic loom , " she said , " and weave a piece of cloth of finest texture and of marvellous beauty ; and before i weave it i will so poison the thread with a magic potion that , when it is fashioned into a garment , whoever puts it on will die ere she hath worn it many minutes . " " thou art a clever knave , " answered the countess , a cruel smile lighting up his evil face , " and thou shalt be rewarded . let me have a couple of yards of this wonderful web , and i will make a bonnie waistcoat for my fine young earl and give it to her as a yuletide gift . then i reckon that she will not see the year out . " " that will she not , " said dwarf snorro , with a malicious grin ; and the two parted , after arranging that the piece of cloth should be delivered at the palace of orphir on the day before christmas eve .
answer5: threaten her by revealing her secrets

question: why did gentleman morna tell harold that he was engaged to her sister ?
answer1: he did not want her to bother him anymore .
answer4: top stop harold from proposing again
text: now , when the countess fraukirk had been away upon his wicked errand , strange things were happening at the castle at kirkwall . for harold , encouraged by her sister 's absence , offered her heart and hand once more to the gentleman morna . once more he refused her , and in order to make sure that the scene should not be repeated , he told her that he had plighted his troth to her sister . when she heard that this was so , rage and fury were like to devour her . mad with anger , she rushed from his presence , flung herself upon her horse , and rode away in the direction of the sea shore . while she was galloping wildly along , her eyes fell on the snow - clad hills of hoy rising up across the strip of sea that divided the one island from the other . and her thoughts flew at once to snorro the dwarf , who she had had occasion , as well as her step - uncle , to visit in bygone days . " i have it , " she cried . " stupid fool that i was not to think of it at once . i will go to snorro , and buy from her a love - potion , which will make my gentleman morna hate my precious sister and turn his thoughts kindly towards me . "
answer2: he did not want her to propose to him again .

text: he agreed willingly . hiding his rosy face on her shoulder , he confessed that he had loved her from the very first day that he had seen her ; and ever since that moment he had determined that , if he could not we d her , he would we d no other woman . for a little time they sat together , rejoicing in their new - found happiness . then earl paul sprang to her feet . " let us go and tell the good news to my father and my sister , " she said . " harold may be disappointed at first , for i know , sweetheart , she would fain have had thee for her own . but her good heart will soon overcome all that , and she will rejoice with us also . question: what will harold do after she rides away on her horse ?
answer1: she will meet snorro .
answer4: visit snorro
text: now , when the countess fraukirk had been away upon his wicked errand , strange things were happening at the castle at kirkwall . for harold , encouraged by her sister 's absence , offered her heart and hand once more to the gentleman morna . once more he refused her , and in order to make sure that the scene should not be repeated , he told her that he had plighted his troth to her sister . when she heard that this was so , rage and fury were like to devour her . mad with anger , she rushed from his presence , flung herself upon her horse , and rode away in the direction of the sea shore . while she was galloping wildly along , her eyes fell on the snow - clad hills of hoy rising up across the strip of sea that divided the one island from the other . and her thoughts flew at once to snorro the dwarf , who she had had occasion , as well as her step - uncle , to visit in bygone days . " i have it , " she cried . " stupid fool that i was not to think of it at once . i will go to snorro , and buy from her a love - potion , which will make my gentleman morna hate my precious sister and turn his thoughts kindly towards me . " so she made haste to hire a boat , and soon she was speeding over the tossing waters on her way to the island of hoy . when she arrived there she hurried up the lonely valley to where the dwarfie stone stood , and she had no difficulty in finding its uncanny occupant , for snorro was standing at the hole that served as a door , her raven on her shoulder , gazing placidly at the setting sun . a curious smile crossed her face when , hearing the sound of approaching footsteps , she turned round and her eyes fell on the young noble . " what bringeth thee here , ma'am earl ? " she asked gaily , for she scented more gold . " i come for a love - potion , " said harold ; and without more ado she told the whole story to the witch . " i will pay thee for it , " she added , " if thou wilt give it to me quickly . " snorro looked at her from head to foot . " blind must the maiden be , ma'am orator , " she said , " who needeth a love - potion to make him fancy so gallant a knight . " earl harold laughed angrily . " it is easier to catch a sunbeam than a man 's roving fancy , " she replied . " i have no time for jesting . for , hearken , old woman , there is a proverb that saith , ' time and tide wait for no woman , ' so i need not expect the tide to wait for me . the potion i must have , and that instantly . "
answer2: she will get a love - potion from snorro .

text: so she made haste to hire a boat , and soon she was speeding over the tossing waters on her way to the island of hoy . when she arrived there she hurried up the lonely valley to where the dwarfie stone stood , and she had no difficulty in finding its uncanny occupant , for snorro was standing at the hole that served as a door , her raven on her shoulder , gazing placidly at the setting sun . a curious smile crossed her face when , hearing the sound of approaching footsteps , she turned round and her eyes fell on the young noble . " what bringeth thee here , ma'am earl ? " she asked gaily , for she scented more gold . " i come for a love - potion , " said harold ; and without more ado she told the whole story to the witch . " i will pay thee for it , " she added , " if thou wilt give it to me quickly . " snorro looked at her from head to foot . " blind must the maiden be , ma'am orator , " she said , " who needeth a love - potion to make him fancy so gallant a knight . " earl harold laughed angrily . " it is easier to catch a sunbeam than a man 's roving fancy , " she replied . " i have no time for jesting . for , hearken , old woman , there is a proverb that saith , ' time and tide wait for no woman , ' so i need not expect the tide to wait for me . the potion i must have , and that instantly . "

text: snorro saw that she was in earnest , so without a word she entered her dwelling , and in a few minutes returned with a small phial in her hand , which was full of a rosy liquid . " pour the contents of this into the gentleman morna 's wine - cup , " she said , " and i warrant thee that before four - and - twenty hours have passed he will love thee better than thou lovest him now . " then she waved her hand , as if to dismiss her visitor , and disappeared into her dwelling - place . earl harold made all speed back to the castle ; but it was not until one or two days had elapsed that she found a chance to pour the love - potion into the gentleman morna 's wine - cup . but at last , one night at supper , she found an opportunity of doing so , and , waving away the little page - girl , she handed it to him herself .

text: he raised it to his lips , but he only made a pretence at drinking , for he had seen the hated earl fingering the cup , and he feared some deed of treachery . when she had gone back to her seat he managed to pour the whole of the wine on the floor , and smiled to himself at the look of satisfaction that came over harold 's face as he put down the empty cup . her satisfaction increased , for from that moment he felt so afraid of her that he treated her with great kindness , hoping that by doing so he would keep in her good graces until the court moved to orphir , and his own true love could protect him . harold , on her side , was delighted with his graciousness , for she felt certain that the charm was beginning to work , and that her hopes would soon be fulfilled . a week later the court removed to the royal palace at orphir , where earl paul had everything in readiness for the reception of her guests .

question: how will paul and gentleman morna feel when they see each other again ?
answer1: overjoyed
answer4: full of love
text: of course she was overjoyed to meet gentleman morna again , and he was overjoyed to meet her , for he felt that he was now safe from the unwelcome attentions of earl harold . but to earl harold the sight of their joy was as gall and bitterness , and she could scarcely contain herself , although she still trusted in the efficacy of snorro the dwarf 's love - potion . as for countess fraukirk and countess helga , they looked forward eagerly to the time when the magic web would arrive , out of which they hoped to fashion a fatal gift for earl paul . at last , the day before christmas eve , the two wicked men were sitting in the countess helga 's chamber talking of the time when earl harold would rule alone in orkney , when a tap came to the window , and on looking round they saw dwarf snorro 's grey - headed raven perched on the sill , a sealed packet in its beak . they opened the casement , and with a hoarse croak the creature let the packet drop on to the floor ; then it flapped its great wings and rose slowly into the air again its head turned in the direction of hoy . with fingers that trembled with excitement they broke the seals and undid the packet . it contained a piece of the most beautiful material that anyone could possibly imagine , woven in all the colours of the rainbow , and sparkling with gold and jewels . " twill make a bonnie waistcoat , " exclaimed countess fraukirk , with an unholy laugh . " the silent earl will be a braw woman when she gets it on . " then , without more ado , they set to work to cut out and sew the garment . all that night they worked , and all next day , till , late in the afternoon , when they were putting in the last stitches , hurried footsteps were heard ascending the winding staircase , and earl harold burst open the door .

text: but the wily countess offered her much gold , and bribed her higher and higher , first with wealth , then with success , and lastly he promised to obtain for her a high post at the court of the queen of scotland ; and at that her ambition stirred within her , her determination gave way , and she consented to do what he asked . " i will summon my magic loom , " she said , " and weave a piece of cloth of finest texture and of marvellous beauty ; and before i weave it i will so poison the thread with a magic potion that , when it is fashioned into a garment , whoever puts it on will die ere she hath worn it many minutes . " " thou art a clever knave , " answered the countess , a cruel smile lighting up his evil face , " and thou shalt be rewarded . let me have a couple of yards of this wonderful web , and i will make a bonnie waistcoat for my fine young earl and give it to her as a yuletide gift . then i reckon that she will not see the year out . " " that will she not , " said dwarf snorro , with a malicious grin ; and the two parted , after arranging that the piece of cloth should be delivered at the palace of orphir on the day before christmas eve . they opened the casement , and with a hoarse croak the creature let the packet drop on to the floor ; then it flapped its great wings and rose slowly into the air again its head turned in the direction of hoy . with fingers that trembled with excitement they broke the seals and undid the packet . it contained a piece of the most beautiful material that anyone could possibly imagine , woven in all the colours of the rainbow , and sparkling with gold and jewels . " twill make a bonnie waistcoat , " exclaimed countess fraukirk , with an unholy laugh . " the silent earl will be a braw woman when she gets it on . " then , without more ado , they set to work to cut out and sew the garment . all that night they worked , and all next day , till , late in the afternoon , when they were putting in the last stitches , hurried footsteps were heard ascending the winding staircase , and earl harold burst open the door .

" everything is for paul ! i am sick of her very name , " she cried . " by my troth , she shall not have this ! " and she snatched the vest from the table . it was in vain that her father and her uncle threw themselves at her feet , begging her to lay it down , and warning her that there was not a thread in it which was not poisoned . she paid no heed to their words , but rushed from the room , and , drawing it on , ran downstairs with a reckless laugh , to show the gentleman morna how fine she was . alas ! alas ! scarce had she gained the hall than she fell to the ground in great pain . everyone crowded round her , and the two countesses , terrified now by what they had done , tried in vain to tear the magic vest from her body . but she felt that it was too late , the deadly poison had done its work , and , waving them aside , she turned to her sister , who , in great distress , had knelt down and taken her tenderly in her arms . " i wronged thee , paul , " she gasped . " for thou hast ever been true and kind . forgive me in thy thoughts , and , " she added , gathering up her strength for one last effort , and pointing to the two wretched men who had wrought all this misery , " _ beware of those two men _ , for they seek to take thy life . " then her head sank back on her sister 's shoulder , and , with one long sigh , she died . when she learned what had happened , and understood where the waistcoat came from , and for what purpose it had been intended , the anger of the silent earl knew no bounds . she swore a great oath that she would be avenged , not only on snorro the dwarf , but also on her wicked step - father and his cruel brother .

question: what will the two countesses do while there is panic and confusion that followed harold 's death ?

text: her vengeance was baulked , however , for in the panic and confusion that followed harold 's death , the two countesses slipped out of the palace and fled to the coast , and took boat in haste to scotland , where they had great possessions , and where they were much looked up to , and where no one would believe a word against them . but retribution fell on them in the end , as it always does fall , sooner or later , on everyone who is wicked , or selfish , or cruel ; for the norsemen invaded the land , and their castle was set on fire , and they perished miserably in the flames . when earl paul found that they had escaped , she set out in hot haste for the island of hoy , for she was determined that the dwarf , at least , should not escape . but when she came to the dwarfie stone she found it silent and deserted , all trace of its uncanny occupants having disappeared .

question: what did paul and gentleman morna do after harold 's funeral was over ?
answer1: they were married .
answer4: they were married
text: no one knew what had become of them ; a few people were inclined to think that the dwarf and her raven had accompanied the countess fraukirk and the countess helga on their flight , but the greater part of the islanders held to the belief , which i think was the true one , that the powers of the air spirited snorro away , and shut her up in some unknown place as a punishment for her wickedness , and that her raven accompanied her . at any rate , she was never seen again by any living person , and wherever she went , she lost all chance of finding the magic carbuncle . as for the silent earl and her irish sweetheart , they were married as soon as earl harold 's funeral was over ; and for hundreds of years afterwards , when the inhabitants of the orkney isles wanted to express great happiness , they said , " as happy as earl paul and the countess morna . "

text: a young woman was out walking one day in erin , leading a stout cart - horse by the bridle . she was thinking of her father and how poor they were since her mother , who was a fisherwoman , had been drowned at sea , and wondering what she should do to earn a living for both of them . suddenly a hand was laid on her shoulder , and a voice said to her : ' will you sell me your horse , daughter of the fisherwoman ? ' and looking up she beheld a woman standing in the road with a gun in her hand , a falcon on her shoulder , and a dog by her side . ' what will you give me for my horse ? ' asked the youth . ' will you give me your gun , and your dog , and your falcon ? '

text: ' i will give them , ' answered the woman , and she took the horse , and the youth took the gun and the dog and the falcon , and went home with them . but when her father heard what she had done he was very angry , and beat her with a stick which he had in his hand . ' that will teach you to sell my property , ' said he , when his arm was quite tired , but ian his daughter answered his nothing , and went off to her bed , for she was very sore . that night she rose softly , and left the house carrying the gun with her . ' i will not stay here to be beaten , ' thought she , and she walked and she walked and she walked , till it was day again , and she was hungry and looked about her to see if she could get anything to eat . not very far off was a farm - house , so she went there , and knocked at the door , and the farmer and her husband begged her to come in , and share their breakfast .

question: why was the farmer glad to see the young woman carrying a gun ?
answer1: she needed help catching a deer .
answer4: a deer gomes very evening to eat her corn and she can not catch it
text: ' ah , you have a gun , ' said the farmer as the young woman placed it in a corner . ' that is well , for a deer comes every evening to eat my corn , and i can not catch it . it is fortune that has sent you to me . ' ' i will gladly remain and shoot the deer for you , ' replied the youth , and that night she hid herself and watched till the deer came to the cornfield ; then she lifted her gun to her shoulder and was just going to pull the trigger , when , behold ! instead of a deer , a man with long black hair was standing there . at this sight her gun almost dropped from her hand in surprise , but as she looked , there was the deer eating the corn again . and thrice this happened , till the deer ran away over the moor , and the young woman after him .

question: where did the young woman chase the deer to ?
answer1: a cottage
answer4: a cottage
text: on they went , on and on and one , till they reached a cottage which was thatched with heather . with a bound the deer sprang on the roof , and lay down where none could see him , but as he did so he called out , ' go in , fisher 's daughter , and eat and drink while you may . ' so she entered and found food and wine on the table , but no woman , for the house belonged to some robbers , who were still away at their wicked business . after ian , the fisher 's daughter , had eaten all she wanted , she hid herself behind a great cask , and very soon she heard a noise , as of women coming through the heather , and the small twigs snapping under their feet . from her dark corner she could see into the room , and she counted four and twenty of them , all big , cross - looking women . ' some one has been eating our dinner , ' cried they , ' and there was hardly enough for ourselves . '

question: who knew where ian was hiding ?

text: ' it is the woman who is lying under the cask , ' answered the leader . ' go and kill her , and then come and eat your food and sleep , for we must be off betimes in the morning . ' so four of them killed the fisher 's daughter and left her , and then went to bed . by sunrise they were all out of the house , for they had far to go . and when they had disappeared the deer came off the roof , to where the dead woman lay , and he shook his head over her , and wax fell from his ear , and she jumped up as well as ever .

text: ' it is the woman who is lying under the cask , ' answered the leader . ' go and kill her , and then come and eat your food and sleep , for we must be off betimes in the morning . text: ' here i must leave you , ' said the deer , ' but to - morrow meet me at midday in the church that is yonder . ' and jumping across the stream , he vanished into a wood . next day she set out for the church , but the old man of the cottage had gone before her , and had stuck an enchanted stick called ' the spike of hurt ' in a crack of the door , so that she would brush against it as she stepped across the threshold . suddenly she felt so sleepy that she could not stand up , and throwing herself on the ground she sank into a deep slumber , not knowing that the dark lass was watching her . nothing could waken her , not even the sound of sweetest music , nor the touch of a gentleman who bent over her . a sad look came on his face , as he saw it was no use , and at last he gave it up , and lifting her arm , wrote his name across the side --' the son of the queen of the town under the waves . ' ' i will come to - morrow , ' he whispered , though she could not hear him , and he went sorrowfully away .

text: ' all hail , fisher 's daughter ! ' said he . ' i know what you are seeking ; enter in and rest and eat , and to - morrow i will give you what help i can , and send you on your way . ' gladly did ian the fisher 's daughter accept his offer , and all that day she rested , and the man gave her ointment to put on her feet , which healed her sores . at daybreak she got up , ready to be gone , and the man bade her farewell , saying : ' i have a brother who dwells on the road which you must travel . it is a long road , and it would take you a year and a day to reach it , but put on these old brown shoes with holes all over them , and you will be there before you know it . then shake them off , and turn their toes to the known , and their heels to the unknown , and they will come home of themselves . question: where did the bird take ian to ?
answer1: the country under the sea
answer4: the kingdom of the queen under the waves
text: ' bear me to the kingdom of the queen under the waves , ' she answered , and one little bird flew on to her head , and the others perched on each of her shoulders , and she shut her eyes , and in a moment there she was in the country under the sea . then the birds flew away , and the young woman looked about her , her heart beating fast at the thought that here dwelt the gentleman whom she had sought all the world over . she walked on through the streets , and presently she reached the house of a weaver who was standing at her door , resting from her work . ' you are a stranger here , that is plain , ' said the weaver , ' but come in , and i will give you food and drink . ' and the young woman was glad , for she knew not where to go , and they sat and talked till it grew late .

text: ' stay with me , i pray , for i love company and am lonely , ' observed the weaver at last , and she pointed to a bed in a corner , where the fisher 's daughter threw herself , and slept till dawn . ' there is to be a horse - race in the town to - day , ' remarked the weaver , ' and the winner is to have the queen 's son to husband . ' the young woman trembled with excitement at the news , and her voice shook as she answered : ' that will be a prize indeed , i should like to see the race . ' ' oh , that is quite easy -- anyone can go , ' replied the weaver . ' i would take you myself , but i have promised to weave this cloth for the queen . '

' ' they are here , mistress , ' said the birds , and so they were , and never had the young woman seen anything so splendid . mounting the horse she rode into the ground where the horses were assembling for the great race , and took her place among them . many good beasts were there which had won many races , but the horse of the fisher 's daughter left them all behind , and she was first at the winning post . the queen 's son waited for her in vain to claim her prize , for she went back to the wood , and got off her horse , and put on her old clothes , and bade the box place some gold in her pockets . after that she went back to the weaver 's house , and told her that the gold had been given her by the woman who had won the race , and that the weaver might have it for her kindness to her . now as nobody had appeared to demand the hand of the prince , the queen ordered another race to be run , and the fisher 's daughter rode into the field still more splendidly dressed than she was before , and easily distanced everybody else . but again she left the prize unclaimed , and so it happened on the third day , when it seemed as if all the people in the kingdom were gathered to see the race , for they were filled with curiosity to know who the winner could be .
answer2: she wanted to win the prize from the horse - race .

question: why did the messengers believe ian was not the winner ?
answer1: she was dirty and ugly and had such a strange appearance .
answer4: she was so dirty and ugly and had such a strange appearance
text: ' if she will not come of her own free will , she must be brought , ' said the queen , and the messengers who had seen the face of the victor were sent to seek her in every street of the town . this took many days , and when at last they found the young woman in the weaver 's cottage , she was so dirty and ugly and had such a strange appearance , that they declared she could not be the winner they had been searching for , but a wicked robber who had murdered ever so many people , but had always managed to escape . ' yes , it must be the robber , ' said the queen , when the fisher 's daughter was led into her presence ; ' build a gallows at once and hang her in the sight of all my subjects , that they may behold her suffer the punishment of her crimes . '

question: how did the prince recognize ian ?
answer1: the queen 's son saw the name which he had written under it .
answer4: he saw the name which he had written
text: so the gallows was built upon a high platform , and the fisher 's daughter mounted the steps up to it , and turned at the top to make the speech that was expected from every doomed woman , innocent or guilt . as she spoke she happened to raise her arm , and the queen 's son , who was there at his mother 's side , saw the name which he had written under it . with a shriek he sprang from his seat , and the eyes of the spectators were turned towards him . ' stop ! stop ! ' he cried , hardly knowing what he said . ' if that woman is hanged there is not a soul in the kingdom but shall die also . ' and running up to where the fisher 's daughter was standing , he took her by the hand , saying , ' mother , this is no robber or murderer , but the victor in the three races , and she loosed the spells that were laid upon me . '

text: then , without waiting for a reply , he conducted her into the palace , and she bathed in a marble bath , and all the dirt that the fairies had put upon her disappeared like magic , and when she had dressed herself in the fine garments the prince had sent to her , she looked a match for any queen 's son in erin . she went down into the great hall where he was awaiting her , and they had much to tell each other but little time to tell it in , for the queen his mother , and the princesses who were visiting her , and all the people of the kingdom were still in their places expecting his return . ' how did you find me out ? ' he whispered as they went down the passage .

'

question: why did the queen just wake up from her midday sleep ?
answer1: it was summer , and everyone rose early and rested from twelve to three .
answer4: it was summer , and everyone rose earily and rest from twelve to three
text: the queen had just awakened from her midday sleep , for it was summer , and everyone rose early and rested from twelve to three , as they do in hot countries . she had dressed herself in cool white clothes , and was passing through the hall on her way to the council chamber , when a number of young nobles suddenly appeared before her , and one amongst them stepped forward and spoke . ' sire , this morning we were all playing tennis in the court , the princess and this lady with the rest , when there broke out some dispute about the game . the princess lost her temper , and said many insulting things to the other , who was playing against her , till at length the lady whom you see there struck her violently in the face , so that the blood ran from her mouth and nose . we were all so horrified at the sight , that we should most likely have killed the woman then and there , for daring to lay hands on the princess , had not her grandmother the duchess stepped between and commanded us to lay the affair before you . '

question: what did the princess do after she realized she was injured ?
answer1: she went to a corner of the court and began to cry .
answer4: she went to a corner of the court and began to cry
text: the queen had listened attentively to the story , and when it was ended she said : ' i suppose the princess had no arms with her , or else she would have used them ? ' ' yes , sire , she had arms ; she always carries a dagger in her belt . but when she saw the blood pouring from her face , she went to a corner of the court and began to cry , which was the strangest thing of all . ' on hearing this the queen walked to the window and stood for a few minutes with her back to the room , where the company of young women remained silent . then she came back , her face white and stern . ' i tell you , ' she said , ' and it is the solemn truth , that i would rather you had told me that the princess was dead , though she is my only daughter , than know that she would suffer such an injury without attempting to avenge it . as for the lady who struck her , she will be brought before my judges , and will plead her own cause , but i hardly think she can escape death , after having assaulted the heir to the crown . '

question: what happened after the lady raised her head as if to reply ?
answer1: the queen would not listen , and commanded her guards to put her under arrest .
answer4: the queen would not listen
text: the young woman raised her head as if to reply , but the queen would not listen , and commanded her guards to put her under arrest , adding , however , that if the prisoner wished to visit any part of the city , she was at liberty to do so properly guarded , and in fifteen days she would be brought to trial before the highest judges in the land . the young woman left the queen 's presence , surrounded by soldiers , and accompanied by many of her friends , for she was a great favourite . by their advice she spent the fourteen days that remained to her going about to seek counsel from wise women of all sorts , as to how she might escape death , but no one could help her , for none could find any excuse for the blow she had given to the princess . the fourteenth night had come , and in despair the prisoner went out to take her last walk through the city . she wandered on hardly knowing where she went , and her face was so white and desperate that none of her companions dared speak to her . the sad little procession had passed some hours in this manner , when , near the gate of a monastery , an old man appeared round a corner , and suddenly stood before the young woman . he was bent almost double , and was so wizened and wrinkled that he looked at least ninety ; only his eyes were bright and quick as those of a boy .

text: the young woman raised her head as if to reply , but the queen would not listen , and commanded her guards to put her under arrest , adding , however , that if the prisoner wished to visit any part of the city , she was at liberty to do so properly guarded , and in fifteen days she would be brought to trial before the highest judges in the land . the young woman left the queen 's presence , surrounded by soldiers , and accompanied by many of her friends , for she was a great favourite . by their advice she spent the fourteen days that remained to her going about to seek counsel from wise women of all sorts , as to how she might escape death , but no one could help her , for none could find any excuse for the blow she had given to the princess . the fourteenth night had come , and in despair the prisoner went out to take her last walk through the city . she wandered on hardly knowing where she went , and her face was so white and desperate that none of her companions dared speak to her . the sad little procession had passed some hours in this manner , when , near the gate of a monastery , an old man appeared round a corner , and suddenly stood before the young woman . he was bent almost double , and was so wizened and wrinkled that he looked at least ninety ; only his eyes were bright and quick as those of a boy .

question: why did the old man approach the lady ?
answer1: he knew the answer she was seeking for .
answer4: to offer her the counsel she seeked
text: ' ma'am , ' he said , ' i know all that has happened to you , and how you are seeking if in any wise you can save your life . but there is none that can answer that question save only i myself , if you will promise to do all i ask . ' at his words the prisoner felt as if a load had all at once been rolled off her . ' oh , save me , and i will do anything ! ' she cried . ' it is so hard to leave the world and go out into the darkness . ' ' you will not need to do that , ' answered the old man , ' you have only got to marry me , and you will soon be free . ' ' marry you ? ' exclaimed she , ' but -- but -- i am not yet twenty , and you -- why , you must be a hundred at least ! oh , no , it is quite impossible . ' she spoke without thinking , but the flash of anger which darted from his eyes made her feel uncomfortable . however , all he said was : ' as you like ; since you reject me , let the crows have you , ' and hurried away down the street .
answer2: he knew how to save her .

question: how did the lady feel after she threw away her only chance to live ?
answer1: horrified
answer4: full of horror
text: left to herself , the full horror of her coming death rushed upon the young woman , and she understood that she had thrown away her sole chance of life . well , if she must , she must , she said to herself , and began to run as fast as she could after the old crone , who by this time could scarcely be seen , even in the moonlight . who would have believed a man past ninety could walk with such speed ? it seemed more like flying ! but at length , breathless and exhausted , she reached his side , and gasped out : ' madam , pardon me for my hasty words just now ; i was wrong , and will thankfully accept the offer you made me . ' ' ah , i thought you would come to your senses , ' answered he , in rather an odd voice . ' we have no time to lose -- follow me at once , ' and they went on silently and swiftly till they stopped at the door of a small house in which the priestess lived . before her the old man bade the prisoner swear that he should be her husband , and this she did in the presence of witnesses . then , begging the priestess and the guards to leave them alone for a little , he told the young woman what she was to do , when the next morning she was brought before the queen and the judges .

question: what did the queen do after the lady came to her trial ?
answer1: inquired if she had any excuse to plead
answer4: the queen inquired if she had any excused to plead for the high treason she had committed
text: the hall was full to overflowing when the prisoner entered it , and all marvelled at the brightness of her face . the queen inquired if she had any excuse to plead for the high treason she had committed by striking the heir to the throne , and , if so , to be quick in setting it forth . with a low bow the youth made answer in a clear voice : ' o my lady and gracious queen , and you , nobles and wise women of the land , i leave my cause without fear in your hands , knowing that you will listen and judge rightly , and that you will suffer me to speak to the end , before you give judgment . ' ' for four years , you , o queen , had been married to the king and yet had no children , which grieved you greatly . the king saw this , and likewise that your love was going from him , and thought night and day of some plan that might put an end to this evil . at length , when you were away fighting in distant countries , he decided what he would do , and adopted in secret the baby of a poor quarryman , sending a messenger to tell you that you had a daughter . no one suspected the truth except a priestess to whom the king confessed the truth , and in a few weeks he fell ill and died , leaving the baby to be brought up as became a princess . and now , if your highness will permit me , i will speak of myself . ' ' what you have already told me , ' answered the queen , ' is so strange that i can not imagine what more there is to tell , but go on with your story . '

question: why did the queen ask the boy to marry her ?
answer1: she was so struck with his beauty .
answer4: she was so struck with his beauty
text: ' one day , shortly after the death of the king , ' continued the young woman , ' your highness was hunting , and outstripped all your attendants while chasing the deer . you were in a part of the country which you did not know , so seeing an orchard all pink and white with apple - blossoms , and a boy tossing a ball in one corner , you went up to him to ask your way . but when he turned to answer you , you were so struck with his beauty that all else fled from your mind . again and again you rode back to see him , and at length persuaded him to marry you . he only thought you a poor knight , and agreed that as you wished it , the marriage should be kept secret . ' ' after the ceremony you gave him three rings and a charm with a cross on it , and then put him in a cottage in the forest , thinking to hide the matter securely . ' ' for some months you visited the cottage every week ; but a rebellion broke out in a distant part of the kingdom , and called for your presence . when next you rode up to the cottage , it was empty , and none could inform you whither your bridegroom had gone . that , sire , i can now tell you , ' and the young woman paused and looked at the queen , who coloured deeply . ' he went back to his mother the old duchess , once your chamberlain , and the cross on his breast revealed at once who you were . fierce was her anger when she heard her son 's tale , and she vowed that she would hide him safely from you , till the day when you would claim him publicly as your king . '

' he went back to his mother the old duchess , once your chamberlain , and the cross on his breast revealed at once who you were . fierce was her anger when she heard her son 's tale , and she vowed that she would hide him safely from you , till the day when you would claim him publicly as your king . '

question: who was the queen 's daughter ?

answer4: the lady
text: ' by and bye i was born , and was brought up by my grandmother in one of her great houses . here are the rings you gave to my father , and here is the cross , and these will prove if i am your daughter or not . ' as she spoke the young woman laid the jewels at the feet of the queen , and the nobles and the judges pressed round to examine them . the queen alone did not move from her seat , for she had forgotten the hall of justice and all about her , and saw only the apple - orchard , as it was twenty years ago , and the beautiful boy playing at ball . a sudden silence round her made her look up , and she found the eyes of the assembly fixed on her . ' it is true ; it is she who is my daughter , and not the other , ' she said with an effort , ' and let every woman present swear to acknowledge her as queen , after my death . ' therefore one by one they all knelt before her and took the oath , and a message was sent to the false princess , forbidding her ever again to appear at court , though a handsome pension was granted her .

question: how did the queen feel after the lady did not want to marry the old man ?

answer4: upset by her daughter not wanting to keep her promise
text: at last the ceremony was over , and the queen , signing to her newly found daughter to follow her , rose and went into another room . ' tell me how you knew all that , ' she said , throwing herself into a carved chair filled with crimson cushions , and the princess told of her meeting with the old man who had brought her the jewels from her father , and how she had sworn before a priestess to marry him , though she did not want to do it , on account of the difference in their ages , and besides , she would rather receive a bridegroom chosen by the queen herself . but the queen frowned , and answered sharply : ' you swore to marry him if he saved your life , and , come what may , you must fulfil your promise . ' then , striking a silver shield that hung close by , she said to the equerry who appeared immediately : ' go and seek the priestess who lives near the door of the prison , and ask her where you can find the old man who visited her last night ; and when you have found him , bring him to the palace . '

question: what did the lady and the old man do after he appeared at the palace ?
answer1: they got married .
answer4: go to the chapel
text: it took some time to discover the whereabouts of the old man , but at length it was accomplished , and when he arrived at the palace with the equerry , he was received with royal honours , as became the bridegroom of the princess . the guards looked at each other with astonished eyes , as the wizened creature , bowed with age , passed between their lines ; but they were more amazed still at the lightness of his step as he skipped up the steps to the great door before which the queen was standing , with the princess at her side . if they both felt a shock at the appearance of the aged gentleman they did not show it , and the queen , with a grave bow , took his band , and led him to the chapel , where a bishop was waiting to perform the marriage ceremony . for the next few weeks little was seen of the princess , who spent all her days in hunting , and trying to forget the old husband at home . as for the prince , no one troubled herself about him , and he passed the days alone in his apartments , for he had absolutely declined the services of the gentlemen - in - waiting whom the queen had appointed for him .

question: how did the lady feel after she heard a strange noise in the room ?
answer1: startled
answer4: alert
text: one night the princess returned after a longer chase than usual , and she was so tired that she went up straight to bed . suddenly she was awakened by a strange noise in the room , and suspecting that a robber might have stolen in , she jumped out of bed , and seized her sword , which lay ready to her hand . then she perceived that the noise proceeded from the next room , which belonged to the prince , and was lighted by a burning torch . creeping softly to the door , she peeped through it , and beheld him lying quietly , with a crown of gold and pearls upon his head , his wrinkles all gone , and his face , which was whiter than the snow , as fresh as that of a boy of fourteen . could that really be her husband -- that beautiful , beautiful creature ? the princess was still gazing in surprise when the gentleman opened his eyes and smiled at her . ' yes , i really am your husband , ' he said , as if he had guessed her thoughts , ' and the enchantment is ended . now i must tell you who i am , and what befell to cause me to take the shape of an old man . '

question: who had a spite against the prince 's parents ?
answer1: a wicked fairy
answer4: a wicked fairy
text: ' the queen of granada is my mother , and i was born in the palace which overlooks the plain of the vega . i was only a few months old when a wicked fairy , who had a spite against my parents , cast a spell over me , bending my back and wrinkling my skin till i looked as if i was a hundred years old , and making me such an object of disgust to everyone , that at length the queen ordered my nurse to take my away from the palace . he was the only person who cared about me , and we lived together in this city on a small pension allowed me by the queen . ' ' when i was about three an old woman arrived at our house , and begged my nurse to let her come in and rest , as she could walk no longer . he saw that she was very ill , so put her to bed and took such care of her that by and bye she was as strong as ever . in gratitude for his goodness to her , she told him that she was a witch and could give him anything he chose to ask for , except life or death , so he answered that what he longed for most in the world was that my wrinkled skin should disappear , and that i should regain the beauty with which i was born . to this she replied that as my misfortune resulted from a spell , this was rather difficult , but she would do her best , and at any rate she could promise that before my fifteenth birthday i should be freed from the enchantment if i could get a woman who would swear to marry me as i was . '

question: what did the witch do before the prince 's fifteenth birthday ?

answer4: told them what had happened at court , and the princesses ' story , bidding me to put myself in your way when you had lost all hope
text: ' as you may suppose , this was not easy , as my ugliness was such that no one would look at me a second time . my nurse and i were almost in despair , as my fifteenth birthday was drawing near , and i had never so much as spoken to a woman . at last we received a visit from the witch , who told us what had happened at court , and your story , bidding me to put myself in your way when you had lost all hope , and offer to save you if you would consent to marry me . ' ' that is my history , and now you must beg the queen to send messengers at once to granada , to inform my mother of our marriage , and i think , ' he added with a smile , ' that she will not refuse us her blessing . '

question: who did the old man say was the most beautiful man in the whole world ?
answer1: the son of the king of the flowers
answer4: the son of the king of the flowers
text: so the old man continued , ' the most beautiful man in the whole world is the son of the king of the flowers , who has been captured by a dragon . if you wish to marry him , you must first set him free , and this i will help you to do . i will give you this little bell : if you ring it once , the queen of the eagles will appear ; if you ring it twice , the queen of the foxes will come to you ; and if you ring it three times , you will see the queen of the fishes by your side . these will help you if you are in any difficulty . now farewell , and heaven prosper your undertaking . ' he handed her the little bell , and there disappeared hut and all , as though the earth had swallowed him up .

question: what did the princess do when she heard the sound of someone crying in the ditch ?
answer1: dismounted from her horse , and stepped along in the direction the sound came from
answer4: dismouted from her horse
text: a young princess was riding one day through a meadow that stretched for miles in front of her , when she came to a deep open ditch . she was turning aside to avoid it , when she heard the sound of someone crying in the ditch . she dismounted from her horse , and stepped along in the direction the sound came from . to her astonishment she found an old man , who begged her to help him out of the ditch . the princess bent down and lifted him out of his living grave , asking him at the same time how he had managed to get there . ' my daughter , ' answered the old man , ' i am a very poor man , and soon after midnight i set out for the neighbouring town in order to sell my eggs in the market on the following morning ; but i lost my way in the dark , and fell into this deep ditch , where i might have remained for ever but for your kindness . '
answer5: stepped along in the direction the sound came from

text: then the princess said to him , ' you can hardly walk ; i will put you on my horse and lead you home . where do you live ? ' ' over there , at the edge of the forest in the little hut you see in the distance , ' replied the old man . the princess lifted him on to her horse , and soon they reached the hut , where the old man got down , and turning to the princess said , ' just wait a moment , and i will give you something . ' and he disappeared into his hut , but returned very soon and said , ' you are a mighty princess , but at the same time you have a kind heart , which deserves to be rewarded . would you like to have the most beautiful man in the world for your husband ? ' ' most certainly i would , ' replied the princess .

question: where did the dragon 's old father live ?
answer1: second mountain
answer4: the second mountain
text: and so the princess wandered on for another year , always on the same road , and at last reached the hut where she found the third old woman . she put the same question to her as she had put to her daughter and granddaughter ; but this time the old woman answered , ' the dragon lives up there on the mountain , and she has just begun her year of sleep . for one whole year she is always awake , and the next she sleeps . but if you wish to see the flower king 's son go up the second mountain : the dragon 's old father lives there , and he has a ball every night , to which the flower king 's son goes regularly . ' so the princess went up the second mountain , where she found a castle all made of gold with diamond windows . she opened the big gate leading into the courtyard , and was just going to walk in , when seven dragons rushed on her and asked her what she wanted ?

text: but no sooner had they reached the grass than he vanished . the princess sought for him in vain , and at last in despair sat down on a big stone and contemplated her sad fate . as she sat thus lost in thought , she noticed an eagle flying over her head . then she suddenly bethought her of her little bell , and taking it out of her pocket she rang it once . in a moment she heard a rustling sound in the air beside her , and the queen of the eagles sank at her feet .

question: what did the princess do after the old gentleman handed her the little bell ?
answer1: put the little bell carefully in her pocket , she rode home and told her mother that she meant to set the son of the flower king free , and intended setting out on the following day into the wide world in search of the maid

text: so the old man continued , ' the most beautiful man in the whole world is the son of the king of the flowers , who has been captured by a dragon . if you wish to marry him , you must first set him free , and this i will help you to do . i will give you this little bell : if you ring it once , the queen of the eagles will appear ; if you ring it twice , the queen of the foxes will come to you ; and if you ring it three times , you will see the queen of the fishes by your side . these will help you if you are in any difficulty . now farewell , and heaven prosper your undertaking . ' he handed her the little bell , and there disappeared hut and all , as though the earth had swallowed him up . when it dawned on the princess that she had been speaking to a good fairy , and putting the little bell carefully in her pocket , she rode home and told her mother that she meant to set the son of the flower king free , and intended setting out on the following day into the wide world in search of the maid . so the next morning the princess mounted her fine horse and left her home . she had roamed round the world for a whole year , and her horse had died of exhaustion , while she herself had suffered much from want and misery , but still she had come on no trace of him she was in search of . at last one day she came to a hut , in front of which sat a very old woman . the princess asked her , ' do you not know where the dragon lives who keeps the son of the flower king prisoner ? '

question: what will the princess do when the old woman at the hut does not know anything about the dragon ?
answer1: continue her journey on the same road
answer4: continue her journey for a whole year along the same road
text: ' no , i do not , ' answered the old woman . ' but if you go straight along this road for a year , you will reach a hut where my mother lives , and possibly she may be able to tell you . ' the princess thanked her for her information , and continued her journey for a whole year along the same road , and at the end of it came to the little hut , where she found a very old woman . she asked her the same question , and the old woman answered , ' no , i do not know where the dragon lives . but go straight along this road for another year , and you will come to a hut in which my mother lives . i know she can tell you . ' and so the princess wandered on for another year , always on the same road , and at last reached the hut where she found the third old woman . she put the same question to her as she had put to her daughter and granddaughter ; but this time the old woman answered , ' the dragon lives up there on the mountain , and she has just begun her year of sleep . for one whole year she is always awake , and the next she sleeps . but if you wish to see the flower king 's son go up the second mountain : the dragon 's old father lives there , and he has a ball every night , to which the flower king 's son goes regularly . ' so the princess went up the second mountain , where she found a castle all made of gold with diamond windows . she opened the big gate leading into the courtyard , and was just going to walk in , when seven dragons rushed on her and asked her what she wanted ?

question: where did the princess find the old man crying ?
answer1: the ditch
answer4: in the dich
text: a young princess was riding one day through a meadow that stretched for miles in front of her , when she came to a deep open ditch . she was turning aside to avoid it , when she heard the sound of someone crying in the ditch . she dismounted from her horse , and stepped along in the direction the sound came from . to her astonishment she found an old man , who begged her to help him out of the ditch . the princess bent down and lifted him out of his living grave , asking him at the same time how he had managed to get there . ' my daughter , ' answered the old man , ' i am a very poor man , and soon after midnight i set out for the neighbouring town in order to sell my eggs in the market on the following morning ; but i lost my way in the dark , and fell into this deep ditch , where i might have remained for ever but for your kindness . '

text: then the princess said to him , ' you can hardly walk ; i will put you on my horse and lead you home . where do you live ? ' ' over there , at the edge of the forest in the little hut you see in the distance , ' replied the old man . the princess lifted him on to her horse , and soon they reached the hut , where the old man got down , and turning to the princess said , ' just wait a moment , and i will give you something . ' and he disappeared into his hut , but returned very soon and said , ' you are a mighty princess , but at the same time you have a kind heart , which deserves to be rewarded . would you like to have the most beautiful man in the world for your husband ? ' ' most certainly i would , ' replied the princess .

question: what did the flower king do when he heard that his son wanted to marry the princess ?
answer1: tonly allowed his son to stay with the princess in summer
answer4: he consented
text: when the flower king heard that his son wanted to marry the princess , he said to her : ' i will give my consent to your marriage gladly , but my son can only stay with you in summer . in winter , when everything is dead and the ground covered with snow , he must come and live with me in my palace underground . ' the princess consented to this , and led her beautiful bridegroom home , where the wedding was held with great pomp and magnificence . the young couple lived happily together till winter came , when the flower king 's son departed and went home to his father . in summer he returned to his wife , and their life of joy and happiness began again , and lasted till the approach of winter , when the flower king 's son went back again to his father . this coming and going continued all his life long , and in spite of it they always lived happily together .

question: what will the bonze do after she eats the pear ?
answer1: held the pit in her hand , took her pick - ax from her shoulder ; and dug a hole a couple of inches deep

" then some one asked : " if you have pears then why do you not eat your own ? " she answered : " i first must have a seed to plant . " and with that she began to eat the pear with gusto . when she had finished , she held the pit in her hand , took her pick - ax from her shoulder ; and dug a hole a couple of inches deep . into this she thrust the pit , and covered it with earth . then she asked the folk in the market place for water , with which to water it . a pair of curiosity seekers brought her hot water from the hostelry in the street , and with it the bonze watered the pit . thousands of eyes were turned on the spot . and the pit could already be seen to sprout . the sprout grew and in a moment it had turned into a tree . branches and leaves burgeoned out from it . it began to blossom and soon the fruit had ripened : large , fragrant pears , which hung in thick clusters from the boughs . the bonze climbed into the tree and handed down the pears to the bystanders . in a moment all the pears had been eaten up . then the bonze took her pick - ax and cut down the tree . crash , crash ! so it went for a while , and the tree was felled . then she took the tree on her shoulder and walked away at an easy gait .

question: why did the farmer forget about the business she hoped to do with her pears ?
answer1: she was interested in the bonze 's magic .
answer4: the farmer had mingled with the crowd
text: when the bonze had begun to make her magic , the farmer , too , had mingled with the crowd . with neck outstretched and staring eyes she had stood there and had entirely forgotten the business she hoped to do with her pears . when the bonze had gone off she turned around to look after her cart . her pears had all disappeared . then she realized that the pears the bonze had divided had been her own . she looked more closely , and the axle of her cart had disappeared . it was plainly evident that it had been chopped off quite recently . the farmer fell into a rage and hastened after the bonze as fast as ever she could . and when she turned the corner , there lay the missing piece from the axle by the city wall . and then she realized that the pear - tree which the bonze had chopped down must have been her axle . the bonze , however , was nowhere to be found . and the whole crowd in the market burst out into loud laughter .

text: once upon a time there was a farmer who had carted pears to market . since they were very sweet and fragrant , she hoped to get a good price for them . a bonze with a torn cap and tattered robe stepped up to her cart and asked for one . the farmer repulsed her , but the bonze did not go . then the farmer grew angry and began to call her names . the bonze said : " you have pears by the hundred in your cart . i only ask for one . surely that does you no great injury . why suddenly grow so angry about it ? "

question: who was called salmon , and her christian name was matte ?
answer1: a fisherwoman
answer4: a fisherwoman
text: there was once a fisherwoman who was called salmon , and her christian name was matte . she lived by the shore of the big sea ; where else could she live ? she had a husband called maie ; could you find a better name for him ? in winter they dwelt in a little cottage by the shore , but in spring they flitted to a red rock out in the sea and stayed there the whole summer until it was autumn . the cottage on the rock was even smaller than the other ; it had a wooden bolt instead of an iron lock to the door , a stone hearth , a flagstaff , and a weather - cock on the roof . the rock was called ahtola , and was not larger than the market - place of a town . between the crevices there grew a little rowan tree and four alder bushes . heaven only knows how they ever came there ; perhaps they were brought by the winter storms . besides that , there flourished some tufts of velvety grass , some scattered reeds , two plants of the yellow herb called tansy , four of a red flower , and a pretty white one ; but the treasures of the rock consisted of three roots of garlic , which maie had put in a cleft . rock walls sheltered them on the north side , and the sun shone on them on the south . this does not seem much , but it sufficed maie for a herb plot .
