question: what did matte and maie fish for in the spring ?
answer1: salmon
answer4: salmon
text: all good things go in threes , so matte and her husband fished for salmon in spring , for herring in summer , and for cod in winter . when on saturdays the weather was fine and the wind favourable , they sailed to the nearest town , sold their fish , and went to church on sunday . but it often happened that for weeks at a time they were quite alone on the rock ahtola , and had nothing to look at except their little yellow - brown dog , which bore the grand name of princess , their grass tufts , their bushes and blooms , the sea bays and fish , a stormy sky and the blue , white - crested waves . for the rock lay far away from the land , and there were no green islets or human habitations for miles round , only here and there appeared a rock of the same red stone as ahtola , besprinkled day and night with the ocean spray . matte and maie were industrious , hard - working folk , happy and contented in their poor hut , and they thought themselves rich when they were able to salt as many casks of fish as they required for winter and yet have some left over with which to buy tobacco for the old woman , and a pound or two of coffee for her husband , with plenty of burned corn and chicory in it to give it a flavour . besides that , they had bread , butter , fish , a beer cask , and a buttermilk jar ; what more did they require ? all would have gone well had not maie been possessed with a secret longing which never let him rest ; and this was , how he could manage to become the owner of a cow .

question: why did n't matte want maie to have a cow ?

text: ' what would you do with a cow ? ' asked matte . ' he could not swim so far , and our boat is not large enough to bring him over here ; and even if we had him , we have nothing to feed him on . ' ' we have four alder bushes and sixteen tufts of grass , ' rejoined maie . ' yes , of course , ' laughed matte , ' and we have also three plants of garlic . garlic would be fine feeding for him . ' ' every cow likes salt herring , ' rejoined her husband . ' even princess is fond of fish . ' ' that may be , ' said his wife . ' methinks he would soon be a dear cow if we had to feed him on salt herring . all very well for princess , who fights with the gulls over the last morsel . put the cow out of your head , father , we are very well off as we are . '

question: who appeared on a gaily painted boat ?
answer1: three young women
answer4: three young women
text: maie sighed . he knew well that his wife was right , but he could not give up the idea of a cow . the buttermilk no longer tasted as good as usual in the coffee ; he thought of sweet cream and fresh butter , and of how there was nothing in the world to be compared with them . one day as matte and her husband were cleaning herring on the shore they heard princess barking , and soon there appeared a gaily painted boat with three young women in it , steering towards the rock . they were students , on a boating excursion , and wanted to get something to eat . ' bring us a junket , good father , ' cried they to maie . ' ah ! if only i had such a thing ! ' sighed maie . ' a can of fresh milk , then , ' said the students ; ' but it must not be skim . ' ' yes , if only i had it ! ' sighed the old man , still more deeply . ' what ! have not you got a cow ? '

' matte did not understand . she had never read kalevala and knew nothing of the sea godesses of old , but the students proceeded to explain to her . ' ahti , ' said they , ' is a mighty queen who lives in her dominion of ahtola , and has a rock at the bottom of the sea , and possesses besides a treasury of good things . she rules over all fish and animals of the deep ; she has the finest cows and the swiftest horses that ever chewed grass at the bottom of the ocean . she who stands well with ahti is soon a rich woman , but one must beware in dealing with her , for she is very changeful and touchy . even a little stone thrown into the water might offend her , and then as she takes back her gift , she stirs up the sea into a storm and drags the sailors down into the depths . ahti owns also the fairest maidens , who bear the train of her king wellamos , and at the sound of music they comb their long , flowing locks , which glisten in the water . ' ' oh ! ' cried matte , ' have your worships really seen all that ? ' ' we have as good as seen it , ' said the students . ' it is all printed in a book , and everything printed is true . ' ' i m 'm not so sure of that , ' said matte , as she shook her head .

text: matte did not understand . she had never read kalevala and knew nothing of the sea godesses of old , but the students proceeded to explain to her . ' ahti , ' said they , ' is a mighty queen who lives in her dominion of ahtola , and has a rock at the bottom of the sea , and possesses besides a treasury of good things . she rules over all fish and animals of the deep ; she has the finest cows and the swiftest horses that ever chewed grass at the bottom of the ocean . she who stands well with ahti is soon a rich woman , but one must beware in dealing with her , for she is very changeful and touchy . even a little stone thrown into the water might offend her , and then as she takes back her gift , she stirs up the sea into a storm and drags the sailors down into the depths . ahti owns also the fairest maidens , who bear the train of her king wellamos , and at the sound of music they comb their long , flowing locks , which glisten in the water . ' ' oh ! ' cried matte , ' have your worships really seen all that ? ' ' we have as good as seen it , ' said the students . ' it is all printed in a book , and everything printed is true . ' ' i m 'm not so sure of that , ' said matte , as she shook her head .

text: but the herring were now ready , and the students ate enough for six , and gave princess some cold meat which they happened to have in the boat . princess sat on her hind legs with delight and mewed like a pussy cat . when all was finished , the students handed matte a shining silver coin , and allowed her to fill her pipe with a special kind of tobacco . they then thanked her for her kind hospitality and went on their journey , much regretted by princess , who sat with a woeful expression and whined on the shore as long as she could see a flip of the boat 's white sail in the distance . maie had never uttered a word , but thought the more . he had good ears , and had laid to heart the story about ahti . '

text: ' what would you do with a cow ? ' asked matte . ' he could not swim so far , and our boat is not large enough to bring him over here ; and even if we had him , we have nothing to feed him on . ' ' we have four alder bushes and sixteen tufts of grass , ' rejoined maie . ' yes , of course , ' laughed matte , ' and we have also three plants of garlic . garlic would be fine feeding for him . ' ' every cow likes salt herring , ' rejoined her husband . ' even princess is fond of fish . ' ' that may be , ' said his wife . ' methinks he would soon be a dear cow if we had to feed him on salt herring . all very well for princess , who fights with the gulls over the last morsel . put the cow out of your head , father , we are very well off as we are . ' maie sighed . he knew well that his wife was right , but he could not give up the idea of a cow . the buttermilk no longer tasted as good as usual in the coffee ; he thought of sweet cream and fresh butter , and of how there was nothing in the world to be compared with them . one day as matte and her husband were cleaning herring on the shore they heard princess barking , and soon there appeared a gaily painted boat with three young women in it , steering towards the rock . they were students , on a boating excursion , and wanted to get something to eat . ' bring us a junket , good father , ' cried they to maie . ' ah ! if only i had such a thing ! ' sighed maie . ' a can of fresh milk , then , ' said the students ; ' but it must not be skim . ' ' yes , if only i had it ! ' sighed the old man , still more deeply . ' what ! have not you got a cow ? ' but the herring were now ready , and the students ate enough for six , and gave princess some cold meat which they happened to have in the boat . princess sat on her hind legs with delight and mewed like a pussy cat . when all was finished , the students handed matte a shining silver coin , and allowed her to fill her pipe with a special kind of tobacco . they then thanked her for her kind hospitality and went on their journey , much regretted by princess , who sat with a woeful expression and whined on the shore as long as she could see a flip of the boat 's white sail in the distance . maie had never uttered a word , but thought the more . he had good ears , and had laid to heart the story about ahti . ' how delightful , ' thought he to himself , ' to possess a fairy cow ! how delicious every morning and evening to draw milk from it , and yet have no trouble about the feeding , and to keep a shelf near the window for dishes of milk and junkets ! but this will never be my luck . '

text: the old woman allowed herself to be talked over , and so they rowed out with the net . when they reached the deepest part of the water , he began to hum the words of the magic rhyme , altering the words to suit the longing of his heart : oh , ahti , with the long , long beard , who dwellest in the deep blue sea , finest treasures have i heard , and glittering fish belong to thee . the richest pearls beyond compare , are stored up in thy realm below , and ocean 's cows so sleek and fair , feed on the grass in thy green meadow . queen of the waters , far and near , i ask not of thy golden store , i wish not jewels of pearl to wear , nor silver either , ask i for , but one is odd and even is two , so give me a cow , sea - queen so bold , and in return i l ll give to you , a slice of the moon , and the sun 's gold . ' what 's that you r re humming ? ' asked the old woman .

text: both rose . the summer night was as dark as if it had been october , the weather - cock creaked , and the storm was raging in every direction . as they went out the sea lay around them as white as now , and the spray was dashing right over the fisher - hut . in all her life matte had never remembered such a night . to launch the boat and put to sea to rescue the net was a thing not to be thought of . the fisherwoman and her husband stood aghast on the doorstep , holding on fast by the doorpost , while the foam splashed over their faces . ' did i not tell thee that there is no luck in sunday fishing ? ' said matte sulkily ; and her husband was so frightened that he never even once thought of ahti 's cows . as there was nothing to be done , they went in . their eyes were heavy for lack of slumber , and they slept as soundly as if there had not been such a thing as an angry sea roaring furiously around their lonely dwelling . when they awoke , the sun was high in the heavens , the tempest had cased , and only the swell of the sea rose in silvery heavings against the red rock .

text: both rose . the summer night was as dark as if it had been october , the weather - cock creaked , and the storm was raging in every direction . as they went out the sea lay around them as white as now , and the spray was dashing right over the fisher - hut . in all her life matte had never remembered such a night . to launch the boat and put to sea to rescue the net was a thing not to be thought of . the fisherwoman and her husband stood aghast on the doorstep , holding on fast by the doorpost , while the foam splashed over their faces . ' did i not tell thee that there is no luck in sunday fishing ? ' said matte sulkily ; and her husband was so frightened that he never even once thought of ahti 's cows . as there was nothing to be done , they went in . their eyes were heavy for lack of slumber , and they slept as soundly as if there had not been such a thing as an angry sea roaring furiously around their lonely dwelling . when they awoke , the sun was high in the heavens , the tempest had cased , and only the swell of the sea rose in silvery heavings against the red rock . ' what can that be ? ' said the old man , as he peeped out of the door . ' it looks like a big seal , ' said matte . ' as sure as i live , it 's a cow ! ' exclaimed maie . and certainly it was a cow , a fine red cow , fat and flourishing , and looking as if it had been fed all its days on spinach . it wandered peacefully up and down the shore , and never so much as even looked at the poor little tufts of grass , as if it despised such fare . matte could not believe her eyes . but a cow he seemed , and a cow he was found to be ; and when the old man began to milk him , every pitcher and pan , even to the baler , was soon filled with the most delicious milk . the old woman troubled her head in vain as to how he came there , and sallied forth to seek for her lost net . she had not proceeded far when she found it cast up on the shore , and so full of fish that not a mesh was visible .

text: ' we shall require a better house , ' said maie the following summer ; ' the old one is too small for ourselves and the women . ' ' yes , ' said matte . so she built a large cottage , with a real lock to the door , and a store - house for fish as well ; and she and her women caught such quantities of fish that they sent tons of salmon , herring , and cod to russian and sweden . ' i am quite overworked with so many folk , ' said maie ; ' a boy to help me would not come amiss . question: what did maie promise to ahti for the cows he received ?
answer1: the gold from the sun and the silver from the moon
answer4: gold from the sun and silver from the moon
text: the old woman allowed herself to be talked over , and so they rowed out with the net . when they reached the deepest part of the water , he began to hum the words of the magic rhyme , altering the words to suit the longing of his heart : oh , ahti , with the long , long beard , who dwellest in the deep blue sea , finest treasures have i heard , and glittering fish belong to thee . the richest pearls beyond compare , are stored up in thy realm below , and ocean 's cows so sleek and fair , feed on the grass in thy green meadow . queen of the waters , far and near , i ask not of thy golden store , i wish not jewels of pearl to wear , nor silver either , ask i for , but one is odd and even is two , so give me a cow , sea - queen so bold , and in return i l ll give to you , a slice of the moon , and the sun 's gold . ' what 's that you r re humming ? ' asked the old woman . ' whence comes this gust of wind ? ' said maie ; and as he spoke the sea opened and swallowed up the steamer . maie sank to the bottom like a stone , but , stretching out his arms and legs , he rose to the surface , where he found the fiddler 's fiddle , and used it as a float . at the same moment he saw close beside him the terrible head of ahti , and she had only half a beard ! ' why did you throw stones at me ? ' roared the sea - queen . ' oh , your majesty , it was a mistake ! put some bear 's grease on your beard and that will soon make it grow again . ' ' dame , did i not give you all you asked for -- nay , even more ? ' ' truly , truly , your majesty . many thanks for the cows . ' ' well , where is the gold from the sun and the silver from the moon that you promised me ? ' ' ah , your majesty , they have been scattered day and night upon the sea , except when the sky was overcast , ' slyly answered maie . ' i 'll teach you ! ' roared the sea - queen ; and with that she gave the fiddle such a ' puff ' that it sent the old man up like a sky - rocket on to his island . there princess lay , as famished as ever , gnawing the carcase of a crow . there sat matte in her ragged grey jacket , quite alone , on the steps of the old hut , mending a net .

text: ' heavens , father , ' said she , ' where are you coming from at such a whirlwind pace , and what makes you in such a dripping condition ? ' maie looked around him amazed , and said , ' where is our two - storey house ? ' ' what house ? ' asked his wife . ' our big house , and the flower garden , and the women and the maids , and the thirty beautiful cows , and the steamer , and everything else ? ' ' you are talking nonsense , father , ' said she . ' the students have quite turned your head , for you sang silly songs last evening while we were rowing , and then you could not sleep till early morning . we had stormy weather during the night , and when it was past i did not wish to waken you , so rowed out alone to rescue the net . ' ' but i v ve seen ahti , ' rejoined maie . ' you v ve been lying in bed , dreaming foolish fancies , father , and then in your sleep you walked into the water . ' ' but there is the fiddle , ' said maie . ' a fine fiddle ! it is only an old stick . no , no , old man , another time we will be more careful . good luck never attends fishing on a sunday . '

question: where did the old woman and her husband live ?
answer1: in a dear little cottage by the side of a burn
answer4: in a dear little cottage by the side of a burn
text: there was once an old woman and her husband , who lived in a dear little cottage by the side of a burn . they were a very canty and contented couple , for they had enough to live on , and enough to do . indeed , they considered themselves quite rich , for , besides their cottage and their garden , they possessed two sleek cows , five hens and a cock , an old cat , and two kittens . the old woman spent her time looking after the cows , and the hens , and the garden ; while the old man kept himself busy spinning . one day , just after breakfast , the old man thought that he would like an oatmeal bannock for his supper that evening , so he took down his bakeboard , and put on his girdle , and baked a couple of fine cakes , and when they were ready he put them down before the fire to harden .

text: there was once an old woman and her husband , who lived in a dear little cottage by the side of a burn . they were a very canty and contented couple , for they had enough to live on , and enough to do . indeed , they considered themselves quite rich , for , besides their cottage and their garden , they possessed two sleek cows , five hens and a cock , an old cat , and two kittens . the old woman spent her time looking after the cows , and the hens , and the garden ; while the old man kept himself busy spinning . one day , just after breakfast , the old man thought that he would like an oatmeal bannock for his supper that evening , so he took down his bakeboard , and put on his girdle , and baked a couple of fine cakes , and when they were ready he put them down before the fire to harden .

text: while they were toasting , his wife came in from the byre , and sat down to take a rest in her great arm - chair . presently her eyes fell on the bannocks , and , as they looked very good , she broke one through the middle and began to eat it . when the other bannock saw this it determined that it should not have the same fate , so it ran across the kitchen and out of the door as fast as it could . and when the old man saw it disappearing , he ran after it as fast as his legs would carry him , holding his spindle in one hand and his distaff in the other . but he was old , and the bannock was young , and it ran faster than he did , and escaped over the hill behind the house . it ran , and it ran , and it ran , until it came to a large newly thatched cottage , and , as the door was open , it took refuge inside , and ran right across the floor to a blazing fire , which was burning in the first room that it came to .

" so he jumped up with his lint and his lint cards , and the seamstress jumped up with her great shears , and one apprentice grasped the line measure , while another took up the saucer full of pins ; and they all tried to catch the wee bannock . but it dodged them round and round the fire , and at last it got safely out of the door and ran down the road , with one of the apprentices after it , who tried to snip it in two with her shears . it ran too quickly for her , however , and at last she stopped and went back to the house , while the wee bannock ran on until it came to a tiny cottage by the roadside . it trundled in at the door , and there was a weaver sitting at her loom , with her husband beside her , winding a clue of yarn .

text: but it was not so easy to get hold of the wee bannock . it was in vain that the goodwife threw his clue at it , and that the goodman tried to chase it into a corner and knock it down with her shuttle . it dodged , and turned , and twisted , like a thing bewitched , till at last it flew out at the door again , and vanished down the hill , " for all the world , " as the old man said , " like a new tarred sheep , or a daft cow . " in the next house that it came to it found the goodwife in the kitchen , kirning . he had just filled his kirn , and there was still some cream standing in the bottom of his cream jar . " come away , little bannock , " he cried when he saw it . " thou art come in just the nick of time , for i am beginning to feel hungry , and i 'll have cakes and cream for my dinner . "

answer4: split it in half and share it
text: " oh , janet , " cried the goodman in surprise , " here comes in a little bannock . it looks rare and good to eat . i ' ll have one half of it . " " and i 'll have the other half , " cried the goodwife . " hit it over the back with your cloving - stick , sandy , and knock it down . quick , or it will be out at the door again . " but the bannock played " jook - about , " and dodged behind a chair . " hoot ! " cried janet contemptuously , for he thought that his wife might easily have hit it , and he threw his heckle at it . but the heckle missed it , just as his wife 's cloving - rod had done , for it played " jook - about " again , and flew out of the house .

question: where did the bannock escape to after running away from the farmhouse ?
answer1: a little cottage standing among the heather
answer4: a little cottage
text: this time it ran up a burnside till it came to a little cottage standing among the heather . here the goodwife was making porridge for the supper in a pot over the fire , and his wife was sitting in a corner plaiting ropes of straw with which to tie up the cow . " oh , jock ! come here , come here , " cried the goodwife . " you are crying for a little bannock for your supper ; come here , histie , quick , and help me to catch it . " " ay , ay , " assented jock , jumping to her feet and hurrying across the little room . " but where is it ? i can not see it . " " there , woman , there , " cried her husband , " under that chair . run thou to that side ; i will keep to this . "

" save us and help us , " he exclaimed , stopping with the spoon half - way to his mouth . " there 's a wee bannock come in to warm itself at our fireside . question: why did the bannock always run to the fire in the houses ?
answer1: it wanted to warm itself .
answer4: it was cold
text: while they were toasting , his wife came in from the byre , and sat down to take a rest in her great arm - chair . presently her eyes fell on the bannocks , and , as they looked very good , she broke one through the middle and began to eat it . when the other bannock saw this it determined that it should not have the same fate , so it ran across the kitchen and out of the door as fast as it could . and when the old man saw it disappearing , he ran after it as fast as his legs would carry him , holding his spindle in one hand and his distaff in the other . but he was old , and the bannock was young , and it ran faster than he did , and escaped over the hill behind the house . it ran , and it ran , and it ran , until it came to a large newly thatched cottage , and , as the door was open , it took refuge inside , and ran right across the floor to a blazing fire , which was burning in the first room that it came to . " if there be one thing i am fond of , it is a glass of ale and a well - toasted cake , " she cried . " so come inside here , and welcome to you . " but as soon as the little bannock heard of the ale , it turned and ran out of the smithy as fast as it could , and the disappointed smith picked up her hammer and ran after it . and when she saw that she could not catch it , she flung her heavy hammer at it , in the hope of knocking it down , but , luckily for the little cake , she missed her aim . after this the bannock came to a farmhouse , with a great stack of peats standing at the back of it . in it went , and ran to the fireside . in this house the mistress had all the lint spread out on the floor , and was cloving it with an iron rod , while the master was heckling what she had already cloven . so jock ran into the dark corner behind the chair ; but , in her hurry , she tripped and fell , and the wee bannock jumped over her and flew laughing out at the door . through the whins and up the hillside it ran , and over the top of the hill , to a shepherd 's cottage on the other side . the inmates were just sitting down to their porridge , and the goodwife was scraping the pan . " save us and help us , " he exclaimed , stopping with the spoon half - way to his mouth . " there 's a wee bannock come in to warm itself at our fireside . " " sneck the door , " cried the wife , " and we l ll try to catch it . it would come in handy after the porridge . "

question: why did the goodman want to catch the bannock ?
answer1: she did not have enough to eat at supper .
answer4: she did not eat enough for dinner
text: " what 's that ? " said she , " for the bowl of brose that i had at supper - time was not very big . " " catch it , then , " answered her husband , " and i 'll have a bit , too . quick ! quick ! throw your coat over it or it will be away . " so the goodman threw her coat right on the top of the little bannock , and almost managed to smother it ; but it struggled bravely , and got out , breathless and hot , from under it . then it ran out into the grey light again , for night was beginning to fall , and the goodman ran out after it , without her coat . she chased it and chased it through the stackyard and across a field , and in amongst a fine patch of whins . then she lost it ; and , as she was feeling cold without her coat , she went home .

question: where did the bannock fall into ?
answer1: a fox 's hole
answer4: a fox 's gole
text: as for the poor little bannock , it thought that it would creep under a whin bush and lie there till morning , but it was so dark that it never saw that there was a fox 's hole there . so it fell down the fox 's hole , and the fox was very glad to see it , for she had had no food for two days . " oh , welcome , welcome , " she cried ; and she snapped it through the middle with her teeth , and that was the end of the poor wee bannock . and if a moral be wanted for this tale , here it is : that people should never be too uplifted or too cast down over anything , for all the good folk in the story thought that they were going to get the bannock , and , lo and behold ! the fox got it after all .

question: where did the fisherwoman live ?
answer1: near the queen 's castle
answer4: near the queen 's castle
text: once upon a time there was a fisherwoman , who lived near the queen 's castle , and caught fish for the queen 's table . one day when she had gone fishing , she could not catch a thing . try as she might , no matter how she baited or flung , not the tiniest fish would bite ; but when this had gone on for a while , a head rose from the water and said : " if you will give me the first new thing that has come into your house , you shall catch fish a - plenty ! " then the woman agreed quickly , for she could think of no new thing that might have come into the house . so she caught fish all day long , and as many as she could wish for , as may well be imagined .

question: what happened when the daughter went down to the boat ?
answer1: it moved off with a rush .

text: then the daughter found she had forgotten her handkerchief , and went down to the boat to get it . but no sooner was she in the boat than it moved off with a rush , and no matter how hard the youth worked against it with the oars , it was all in vain . the boat drove on and on , all night long , and at last she came to a white strand , far , far away . she stepped ashore , and after she had gone a while she met an old woman with a great , white beard . " what is this country called ? " asked the youth . " whiteland , " was the woman 's answer , and she asked the youth where she came from , and what she wanted , and the latter told her . " if you keep right on along the shore , " said the woman , " you will come to three princes , buried in the earth so that only their heads show . then the first will call you -- and he is the oldest -- and beg you very hard to come to him and help him ; and the next will do the same ; but you must go to neither of them ; walk quickly past them , and act as though you neither saw nor heard them . but go up to the third , and do what he asks of you , for then you will make your fortune . "

text: but when she came out in the morning , the princes were out of the ground up to their ankles . the third night came a troll who had nine heads and nine whips , and she beat and whipped the youth so severely that at last she fainted . then the troll took her and flung her against the wall , and as she did so the bottle fell down , and its whole contents poured over the youth , and she was at once sound and whole again . then she did not delay , but grasped the sword , killed the troll , and when she came out in the morning , the princes were entirely out of the ground . so she chose the youngest of them to be her king , and lived long with him in peace and happiness . but at last she was minded to travel home , and see how her parents fared . this did not suit her king ; but since she wanted to go so badly , and finally was on the point of departure , he said to her : " one thing you must promise me , that you will only do what your mother tells you to do , but not what your father tells you to do . text: but when she came out in the morning , the princes were out of the ground up to their ankles . the third night came a troll who had nine heads and nine whips , and she beat and whipped the youth so severely that at last she fainted . then the troll took her and flung her against the wall , and as she did so the bottle fell down , and its whole contents poured over the youth , and she was at once sound and whole again . then she did not delay , but grasped the sword , killed the troll , and when she came out in the morning , the princes were entirely out of the ground . so she chose the youngest of them to be her king , and lived long with him in peace and happiness . but at last she was minded to travel home , and see how her parents fared . this did not suit her king ; but since she wanted to go so badly , and finally was on the point of departure , he said to her : " one thing you must promise me , that you will only do what your mother tells you to do , but not what your father tells you to do . " and this she promised . then he gave her a ring which had the power of granting two wishes to the one who wore it . so she wished herself home , and her parents could not get over their surprise at seeing how fine and handsome she had become .

text: at any rate , her poor young husband was sorely to be pitied , for he was left with a little baby - girl to bring up , and , as times were bad , he had not much to live on . but he loved his baby dearly , and worked all day amongst his cows , and pigs , and hens , in order to earn enough money to buy food and clothes for both himself and her . now , on the morning of which i am speaking , he rose very early and went out to feed his pigs , for rent - day was coming on , and he intended to take one of them , a great , big , fat creature , to the market that very day , as he thought that the price that it would fetch would go a long way towards paying his rent . and because he thought so , his heart was light , and he hummed a little song to himself as he crossed the yard with his bucket on one arm and his baby - girl on the other .

text: but the song was quickly changed into a cry of despair when he reached the pig - stye , for there lay his cherished pig on its back , with its legs in the air and its eyes shut , just as if it were going to breathe its last breath . " what shall i do ? what shall i do ? " cried the poor man , sitting down on a big stone and clasping his girl to his breast , heedless of the fact that he had dropped his bucket , and that the pig 's - meat was running out , and that the hens were eating it . question: who looked like a gentleman born ?
answer1: an old man
answer4: old man
text: and as the poor young thing , after having a good cry to himself , was drying his eyes , he chanced to look down the hill , and who should he see coming up it but an old man , who looked like a gentleman born . he was dressed all in green , with a white apron , and he wore a black velvet hood on his head , and a steeple - crowned beaver hat over that , something like those , as i have heard tell , that the men wear in wales . he walked very slowly , leaning on a long staff , and he gave a bit hirple now and then , as if he were lame . as he drew near , the young widower felt it was becoming to rise and curtsey to the gentlewoman , for such he saw him to be .

question: why was the widowed master the most unfortunate man in the world ?
answer1: he lost his wife and his pig .
answer4: lost his wife
text: " madam , " he said , with a sob in his voice , " i bid you welcome to the house of kittlerumpit , although you find its master one of the most unfortunate men in the world . " " hout - tout , " answered the old gentleman , in such a harsh voice that the young man started , and grasped his baby tighter in his arms . " ye have little need to say that . ye have lost your wife , i grant ye , but there were waur losses at shirra - muir . and now your pig is like to die -- i could , maybe , remedy that . but i must first hear how much ye wad gie me if i cured her . " " anything that your ladyship 's madam likes to ask , " replied the widower , too much delighted at having the animal 's life saved to think that he was making rather a rash promise . " very good , " said the old dame , and without wasting any more words he walked straight into the pig - sty .
answer5: now the pig is likely to die

question: what did the old man do while he looked at the dying creature ?
answer1: rocked to and fro and muttering to himself
answer4: mutter to himself
text: he stood and looked at the dying creature for some minutes , rocking to and fro and muttering to himself in words which the widower could not understand ; at least , he could only understand four of them , and they sounded something like this : " pitter - patter , haly water . " then he put his hand into his pocket and drew out a tiny bottle with a liquid that looked like oil in it . he took the cork out , and dropped one of his long gentleman - like fingers into it ; then he touched the pig on the snout and on her ears , and on the tip of her curly tail . no sooner had he done so than up the beast jumped , and , with a grunt of contentment , ran off to its trough to look for its breakfast .

text: now in this fir wood there was an old quarry hole , in the bottom of which was a bonnie spring well , the water of which was always sweet and pure . the young widower was walking near this quarry hole , when , to his astonishment , he heard the whirr of a spinning - wheel and the sound of a voice lilting a song . at first he could not think where the sound came from ; then , remembering the quarry , he laid down his child at a tree root , and crept noiselessly through the bushes on his hands and knees to the edge of the hole and peeped over . he could hardly believe his eyes ! for there , far below him , at the bottom of the quarry , beside the spring well , sat the cruel fairy , dressed in his green frock and tall felt hat , spinning away as fast as he could at a tiny spinning - wheel . and what should he be singing but -- " little kens our guid dame at hame , whippety - stourie is my name . "

question: where did the widowed master go during his walk ?
answer1: in the fir wood behind the house
answer4: the fir wood behind the house
text: " ye promised me what i liked to ask , and i have asked your daughter ; and your daughter i will have , " he replied , " so it is useless making such a din about it . but one thing i may tell you , for i know well that the knowledge will not help you . by the laws of fairy - land , i can not take the bairn till the third day after this , and if by that time you have found out my name i can not take her even then . but ye will not be able to find it out , of that i am certain . so i will call back for the girl in three days . " and with that he disappeared round the back of the pig - sty , and the poor father fell down in a dead faint beside the stone . all that day , and all the next , he did nothing but sit in his kitchen and cry , and hug his baby tighter in his arms ; but on the day before that on which the fairy said that he was coming back , he felt as if he must get a little breath of fresh air , so he went for a walk in the fir wood behind the house .

question: why did the widowed master crept softly back to the place where he had left his child ?
answer1: he was worried the old man heard him .
answer4: in case the wicked old dame would hear him and throw some other spell over him
text: the widower man almost cried aloud for joy , for now he had learned the fairy 's secret , and his child was safe . but he dare not , in case the wicked old dame heard him and threw some other spell over him . so he crept softly back to the place where he had left his child ; then , catching her up in his arms , he ran through the wood to his house , laughing , and singing , and tossing her in the air in such a state of delight that , if anyone had met him , they would have been in danger of thinking that he was mad . now this young man had been a merry - hearted maiden , and would have been merry - hearted still , if , since his marriage , he had not had so much trouble that it had made him grow old and sober - minded before his time ; and he began to think what fun it would be to tease the fairy for a few minutes before he let him know that he had found out his name .
answer2: he was worried that the old man would throw some spell at him .

question: what did the widowed master do after he saw the old man coming up the hill ?
answer1: crumpled up his nice clean cap , and screwed up his face , and pretended to be in great distress and to be crying bitterly
answer4: crumpled up his nice clean cap , and screwed up his face , and preteneded to be in great distress
text: so next day , at the appointed time , he went out with his girl in his arms , and seated himself on the big stone where he had sat before ; and when he saw the old dame coming up the hill , he crumpled up his nice clean cap , and screwed up his face , and pretended to be in great distress and to be crying bitterly . the fairy took no notice of this , however , but came close up to him , and said , in his harsh , merciless voice , " good husband of kittlerumpit , ye ken the reason of my coming ; give me the bairn . " then the young father pretended to be in sorer distress than ever , and fell on his knees before the wicked old man and begged for mercy .

question: what did the widowed master want to give to the old man instead of his daughter ?
answer1: the pig
answer4: the pig
text: " oh , sweet madam master , " he cried , " spare me my bairn , and take , and thou wilt , the pig instead . " " we have no need of bacon where i come from , " answered the fairy coldly ; " so give me the laddie and let me begone -- i have no time to waste in this wise . " " oh , dear gentleman mine , " pleaded the goodwife , " if thou wilt not have the pig , wilt thou not spare my poor bairn and take me myself ? " the fairy stepped back a little , as if in astonishment . " art thou mad , man , " he cried contemptuously , " that thou proposest such a thing ? who in all the world would care to take a plain - looking , red - eyed , dowdy husband like thee with them ? "

question: why did n't the widowed master tease the old man anymore ?
answer1: the widowed master became angry at him .
answer4: he got mad at the old man
text: " oh , sweet madam master , " he cried , " spare me my bairn , and take , and thou wilt , the pig instead . " " we have no need of bacon where i come from , " answered the fairy coldly ; " so give me the laddie and let me begone -- i have no time to waste in this wise . " " oh , dear gentleman mine , " pleaded the goodwife , " if thou wilt not have the pig , wilt thou not spare my poor bairn and take me myself ? " the fairy stepped back a little , as if in astonishment . " art thou mad , man , " he cried contemptuously , " that thou proposest such a thing ? who in all the world would care to take a plain - looking , red - eyed , dowdy husband like thee with them ? " now the young master of kittlerumpit knew that he was no beauty , and the knowledge had never vexed him ; but something in the fairy 's tone made him feel so angry that he could contain himself no longer . " in troth , fair madam , i might have had the wit to know that the like of me is not fit to tie the shoe - string of the high and mighty prince , whippety - stourie ! " if there had been a charge of gunpowder buried in the ground , and if it had suddenly exploded beneath his feet , the wicked fairy could not have jumped higher into air . and when he came down again he simply turned round and ran down the brae , shrieking with rage and disappointment , for all the world , as an old book says , " like an owl chased by wizards . "
answer5: the old man 's tone made him angry
